description:
We came here hoping to check out their bar in the back --Hideout. Unfortunately, it was closed when we arrived, so we stayed at Dalva anyways. We had two rounds of the Gold Rush, which was essentially a mix of whiskey and honey.

Soon enough, we realized Hideout was open, so we ventured over to the little speakeasy bar in the back. I had the bartender surprise me with a drink since the menu was too extensive and I was too indecisive, but he made a solid drink whatever it was. We ended up upstairs where there's more seating in a very intimate and dim-lit room. The place eluded with a dark and mysterious atmosphere --very fitting for a date night.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Enter Dalva on Albion St., go all the way to back of the bar, there's a little hallway leading to a smaller bar called the Hideout. I came here with a date last night and I was super excited because I love stumbling onto secret, unassuming bars-within-bars, speakeasy-type situations; so the concept here is on point, but sadly the execution not so great - it was cozy, but kinda musty. I would love it if they even put in a little more effort with lighting or candles, maybe even some more artwork? There also seems to be an upstairs area where we heard laughter but couldn't figure out if it's additional private seating or just the upstairs office.

I had a moscow mule and it was diluted-ish, and my date had the Honey Badger which was actually really good and not too sweet.

The bartender was a woman who was super friendly and gave tips on other bars.

Also they take card, some reviews mention that it's cash only, not the case (anymore?)
author: Farrah N.

description:
This review is for the bartender David(at least that's what he claimed) in the Hideout, the entrance for which is located at the back of Dalva. 
This guy was just extremely rude and unprofessional!
My friends and I (group of 6) were having our drinks when some of us stepped out for about 5 mins. When we got back all our drinks (pretty much untouched) were all cleared out! When we brought this up, David, who is now standing at our table is saying things like "looks like you are asking for free drinks " and"how many free drinks would y'all like?" in the rudest and most condescending manner. He also seemed really intoxicated! While we tried numerous times to just explain what happened he kept interrupting without really listening. When we felt he was being rude, we asked to see the manager and he says "I'm the manager" when he wasn't!! (We checked on this with some other employees)
Really unpleasant individual that ruins the reputation of what otherwise seems like a decent bar.
author: Swetha S.

description:
We were looking to have a nice drink and stumbled upon Dalva. Wasn't crowded at all around 8pm on Saturday and we actually ducked behind to the Hideout. Which is basically the equivalent to the Varnish behind Cole's in LA.

I had the Pineapple Unicorn, which has pineapple rum, strawberry brandy, blood orange, lemon, puppies and rainbows. It was exactly as described and I'm sure if you have enough of these you will feel like you're with puppies and rainbows. It was delicious, and seriously what's not to love about this combination. My husband had some sort of gin drink which I support whole heartedly, they had a cheeky comment printed on their menu about if you order a drink with vodka they'll just give you gin or brandy.

It's worth a dip into, I promise and please order a pineappe unicorn. Parking I guess is horrendous, I walked.
author: Amy K.

description:
Great bar! I went here for a date and we ordered drinks off the beer menu in the back "hideout" room. Service was quick and the beer was delicious - a sour beer they had on the menu really hit the spot, which was exciting since it was my time trying sour beer!

Cool vibe here, lots of seating, and great selection of drinks. This is an excellent spot to hit up in SF if you're on a bar crawl in the neighborhood.
author: Chelsey B.

description: What can I say, after years away but years of going here it is as medicocre as usual and deserves three stars. However the one star is for your pathetic Hideout. Not only did you ruin a decent backroom, you filled it with pretentious chicks who are only there to try and score free drinks from your pathetic sleazy albatross print wearing douchebag bartender. If I ever come back it will be to correct this stain on Mother Nature.
author: Shad M.

description: The bouncer, Travis Lafuof, is a piece of shit. He choked out my friend, who happens to be brown with a bunch of tattoos. He violently assaulted him because he asked to see his ID after he had already seen it. The situation was completely uncalled for. He choked out my friend, and even shoved his girlfriend. He has no respect. You cannot trust people that thrive off of power trips. Please don't go to this bar, unless you're willing to risk being racially profiled and assaulted by a privileged white dude with no morals. The employees do not seem happy. I'm not sure what the dynamics of the work space are, but they do not seem healthy.
author: Maya L.

description: Don't go here you will get choked out by the bouncers. They checked our ID and asked for it a second time while we were in the restroom and when we questioned why he grabbed my friend's neck with his elbow. And shoved my me and my girlfriends. Travis is a violent worker and should not have assaulted us. He needs to be fired ASAP because he went from 0-100 when it was unnecessary. You've lost a great group of customers. Check yourself.
author: Alex B.

description: The service was mediocre and the staff neglectful. We had to leave because of medical issues. The doorman insisted on chain smoking at the door. Please note I mean, literally, at the door. This means the smoke billows into the establishment. The room filled with smoke and it was constant because of the habit. We couldn't breathe. Our clothes and hair are saturated. We didn't want to leave but we had to. I'm surprised they let the doorman do this to their revenue.
author: Renee R.

description:
Hidden in the rear of Hideout, this somewhat divey-looking cocktail bar has a lot of good attributes, whether inexpensive, well-crafted cocktails, or a compact, yet quite decent beer selection that includes good picks from both local and foreign names like Russian River, Hitachino, La Chouffe, and Allagash.

It's a fairly intimate place and it can get crowded fast at peak times. But service is on point, and it's not a bad choice among many in this area.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I've been to Dalva and the Hideout - truthfully, Dalva isn't THAT impressive but the Hideout is pretty neat. It's a little bit more intimate and private. Good variety of drinks to satisfy your palette. They have pretty high end stuff stocked in the back and the bartenders encourage you to try something new. 

Service here is top-notch -- best I've had in SF.   

The bartender was great to us that night! Thanks for the nice celery G&T!
author: Cindy W.

description: Came here on a Thursday night and ordered the celery gin and tonic. What the drink lacked in physical celery stalk it made up for in drinkability. Feels like I am on a healthy juice cleanse - meeting my 2018 goals! #crushing #winning #suckit
author: Alyssa H.

description:
I don't drink anymore and haven't for a while but I love this bar so much that I need to write a review here. 

Dalva is a bar that's tucked inside of Hideout (if my memory serves me well) and their veggie flavored/inspired drinks are really special. The gin & celery is my absolute favorite! I even took a Lyft all the way here and back to where I planned on going out just to get it. The flavor is not overpowering and is blended quite well.

I've tried some other drinks but it's been a while so I don't recall. Come here if you're into unique drinks and want a cleanse of some sorts.
author: Chelsea W.

description: I WAS PHYSICALLY ASSAULTED !!! Extremely disappointed,  disrespected,  and highly outraged by my experience. Friday night my girlfriend and I went into the bar for a possible drink or two. Our intention was to go to the bathroom 1st. We were carded at the door like normal but then asked again for our ID's a second time while right in front of the bathroom. After I question Travis he proceeded to drag me toward the door in a choke hold and while I yelled having my hands up... I yelled out why are you choking me let go!  Then he shoved my girlfriend at the door. After giving him a long mouthful with the people working there holding him back. I tried to not bash his face in and be a violent human and we left home. For ONE if I did engage and attack him I would be just as a horrible human as him & TWO I HAVE A BACK DISABILITY. HOPE HE GET'S FIRED!!!!!
author: Justin F.

description: Extremely disrescpetful bouncer wanted to ID us to go to the bathroom AFTER we had been ID at the door. When we simply asked why, he proceeded to choke out my friend and drag him outside then shove his girlfriend out the door. Management did not help at all and took 10 minutes to offer a response at all.
author: London R.

description:
Unfortunately we didn't even get the chance to check out the bar as the bouncer Travis was irrationally quick to resort to physical violence when we were confused about showing ID again at the back. (We'd been unaware there was a bar within a bar) Prior to entering we showed ID at front so were naturally confused when Travis demanded very rudely to check again. It didn't take more than a minute before he physically grabbed and choked us absolutely unprovoked, giving me no time to even take out my ID. He handled the situation in the worst possible way, having no reason to be extremely unproffessional, irrational, and accusing us of nothing - we were not inebriated or disturbing anyone at all having literally just entered the building. On top of that, my boyfriend has had a severe back injury in the past and put him at risk for absolutely no reason. The irrational and downright discriminatory attitude Travis Lafouf came on with should not be in a workplace and situation where mediating crowds professionally is priority. For the sake of this institution, the crowd, and the other people who work here, I highly urge investigation of this behavior especially if it results in needless, uncalled for violence. That being said I'd be happy to remove this rating once it's looked into, but for this worker to escalate the situation so terribly is incredibly improper and needs to be spoken on. 

It's a huge shame and disappointment scrolling through reviews and reading people experiencing these rude and discriminatory biases as well. I was intrigued by the vibe, but these grossly unprofessional attitudes takes away from any integrity your establishment may have. You can't excuse this by simply saying "he's worked here for a while." Please don't enable this attitude - it's in bad taste.

Thank you.
author: Grace V.

description: I came here because all the other local bars were busy and this was less crowded. I ordered a whiskey ginger and the bartender was generous on happy hour. While waiting for my friends I started a tab and order another drink, but the bartender at a few points kept coming over to ask if I wanted to close out my tab which I didn't. He later came back and said he was heading home and I HAD TO close out my tab. I've worked in the service industry and I'm pretty sure you can transfer a running tab over to another bartender. I assumed he wanted his tip so I closed out. What baffled me was that he stuck around for another 30 minutes serving other people UNREALISTIC
author: Sandeep C.

description:
Chill spot for drinks. After stopping by ABV down the street for a couple hours, my group and I wandered over to Dalva which was a bit less packed. There's a great little spot that they call the "Hideout" upstairs where there were a bunch of available tables. 

The wait at the bar didn't take too long for 11pm on a Saturday.
author: Emma W.

description: This was a great find! My brother and I really enjoyed. The service and food were excellent!
author: Jason T.

description:
This review is about the hideout at dalva.
Hidden in the back of dalva is the hideout with one guy that I can vouch for that's extremely talented at making craft drinks.

I looked at the menu and nothing really popped at me so I got a boulevardier for me and a whiskey sour for my fiance.

Let me start off by saying I wasn't that impressed by the whiskey sour, due to the fact that they didn't implement egg white.  On the flip side however, they made me a great boulevardier.

It seems as they have the drinks on the menu down so, I could tell just by watching the execution, however I'm sure they'd make a great old fashioned. They also have a cozy room upstairs to sip on your fancy cocktail you just grab and it's secluded so no one is really there to rush.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Lori C and I came in for a drink or two between movies at the Roxie and loved the David Lynch decor, very friendly and efficient bar staff and interesting beers. I winced when I ordered a bottle of Pliny only to see the Russian River Damnation on draft but that's on me.

When we got there, it was pretty empty early on a Saturday night but filled up quickly. Good crowd. Recommended.
author: Brian B.

description: Hands down one of the best bars in the Mission. I'd normally think bartenders are stuck up assholes, but all the people who work at Dalva are super friendly, down to earth and accommodating. They have great prices, play cool videos on their projector, have great music playing all the time and they also make a really tasty Gin Ricky!
author: Joe S.

description:
Nice place for a reasonably-priced drink with some funky atmosphere.   My old-fashioned was pretty damn good, with the orange peel in the drink, and just the right amount of sweetness.   Minus one star for showing a crappy roller derby movie on the video when they could have showed actual roller derby footage from back in the day!

 Would I drink here again, you betcha!
author: Arnold T.

description: I had the house whiskey cocktail-it wasn't good- very watery- difficult to screw up a whiskey cocktail but these guys did it....
author: Ankit B.

description:
Review is for both Dalva & Hideout. Visited in early December.

Husband and I got to Dalva pretty early... around 630 or so. Loved it. Low-key, dimly lit, great drinks. The bartender was friendly. We talked to him for awhile. I had the Tom Collins 2x in Dalva, then we went back to the Hideout and I just let the bartender know what I liked and he made something delicious. Don't remember what it was called. But it was amazing. 

We left after we finished our drinks from the Hideout. We wandered around the mission and did some barhopping. The other bars that we went to sucked so we just came back to Dalva. The crowd had picked up by that time but we were still served right away. The bartender made me something different this time. Don't recall what it was... but again, delicious.
author: Kaitlin F.

description:
Dalva or Hideout, front or back, same location...just take your pick. 

Came here with some girlfriends on a busy and crowded Friday night. We heard of Dalva before as people in the industry, and were excited to check this place out. Got here around 9-10PM at night so the crowds were getting a bit dance-y, slosh-y, and dare I say it...sloppy. But we were looking to wind down and enjoy a couple cocktails/beers.

After walking straight to Hideout in the back, we realized that it was a dark cave-like space where bodies were up against each other...like a dance floor without any DJ or music! The poor bartenders looked horrified and bored because no one was ordering drinks. People seemed to stare at them from their cramped space like festival go-ers stare at DJ's. 

We got lucky and found bar seating and ordered a delicious Hermitage stout and cocktails. As we looked around, the scene in Dalva consisted of a few two-top bar tables and bar stools...tables were pretty scarce. So this isn't really the place to have a huge group come in--don't expect to stay together if that's the case. It's great if you're looking to go out with a roommate or even with your boo. I would consider Dalva to have almost a divey vibe to it on Friday nights after 9:30PM.
author: Jodi H.

description:
One of my favorite cocktail bars in the city. plz take me with you if you go ;___;

The front is Dalva, a dive bar that has happy hour every day from 4 - 7 PM with $4 well drinks and $2 off drafts beers. But the back is where the party is at (interpret that as you will): HIDEOUT, a cocktail bar where they don't believe in vodka. Once 7 PM hits, shimmy over to the back and seek out a bartender called Jason, who will make you a clean mean drink of whatever the heck you want. Their cocktails menu seems to change monthly, which includes new renditions of a varying "classic." Each cocktail will cost you $10, CASH ONLY, but be worth way more.

But really, those cocktails are worth every dollar and then some. I have never enjoyed drinking as much as with the drinks I had that night (this is obv the start of a great relationship). My first was the BOURBON MULE involving my favorites of mint and ginger (Jason overheard my conversation with my drinking partner...given how loud I am, that's not too difficult hahaha). It was the pinnacle trifecta: light, delicious, and inebriating.

My next two drinks came from previous Yelpers' recommendations--I literally gave Jason my phone so he could see the ingredients. The SWITCHEL, made with Venezuelan rum, apple (which they ran out of), lime, ginger, and cinnamon, was another home run. Then came the 16TH STREET SWIZZLE, a fave of Jason's. Don't confuse this with the listed Hideout Swizzle #2 (gin, genepy, lime, pineapple, and orange bitters), as the 16th Street Swizzle is made with Jamaican rum, lime, honey, orgeat, and ginger shrub (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dalva-san-francisco?select=o-ojEQ19lp2A-xdNGn960w#waNr1XmkUqJg0eiYf6kPPQ). It's like a sweet liquid ginger. It's kinda awesome.

My drinking partner started off with an Old Fashioned, later ordering the Clover Club, which they swapped out the grenadine for raspberry puree. Another good drink.

Sometimes Jason had to run to the back room to grab ingredients, which is when I got to chat a bit with the other bartender, David, who has been with Dalva for 16 years. Epic, right!? Srsly, they care about the drinks they make without the snotty pretentious 'tude of some other mixologists (that's Mission versus FiDi for you, I guess), and it makes all the difference.

HIDEOUT = $10 CASH-ONLY COCKTAILS, THE BEST YOU'LL EVER HAVE
author: Adele F.

description: I've checked in here twice, and strangely enough, I can remember both instances!  All jokes aside, bar hopping in the Mission is always fun when there are bars like Dalva around.  The Hideaway is a cool concept, but we weren't feeling it on either occasion.  Drinks are good, reasonably priced from what I remember.  There are lots of bar tables with tall stools for people to congregate around.  Dark and intimate environment with good beats in the background.  Probably wouldn't mind popping in here again.
author: Reena P.

description: This bar is a chill place to go for a couple drinks with some friends. There's also lots of sitting area and a back area too to chill out. Drinks are also decently priced. One thing I didn't like is this place is CASH ONLY. So bring money if you don't wanna pay lots of atm fees
author: Galen W.

description: Cool bar w/ a speakeasy?? Go in bak get ripped off by almost cute asian girl? Dude in front sent me to her for a better drink... Silly! Save ur cash, hit Blondies or Kilowatt for a mixed drink
author: Rigo J.

description:
To the folks at Dalva,

I popped into your bar last night for a quick cocktail and I have to say, your bartender was one of the rudest servers I have ever had the misfortune of running across. He was extremely disrespectful and condescending to me and I couldn't help feeling like it might have been bias-based as I was the only large woman in the entire place (everyone else seemed to be getting wonderful service) that wasn't white or Asian.

I just wanted to let you know that it is NOT okay to treat people like that, regardless of who they are. I am paying a customer, like everyone else there, and while I don't expect special treatment, I do expect common courtesy and respect from someone who's working in customer service.

This is a very diverse city, which is what makes it great, and treating people differently (because you don't feel they belong inside your establishment) is morally unacceptable. It is a shame, because you have such a lovely space and very yummy drinks!

I do hope you take this message to heart and I am sincerely sorry for the attitude of the staff you've hired, as everything else is just wonderful.
author: Evie O.

description:
DRINKS:
I don't have an appreciation for smoky drinks but apparently the drinks from here are very good. I like sweet drinks and they don't really have any here but what I like about this place is the ambiance. The bar is in the back of another bar and the room is very tiny. You feel kind of cozy since its a small room behind a regular bar. 

SERVICE:
Friendly bartenders

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Yes, since its a cool experience to go to a secret bar (kind of).
author: Kelley Y.

description: Why 5 stars?  Well, I like a low key dim lit front bar where you can order a good cocktail, and I love the speak easy in the back where I can just tell the bartender what I like and they make me something - what did I have, who knows, I just said I wanted a whole raw egg in it and he did the rest.  For that 5 stars, probably my fav bar in SF (so far...).
author: Corey A.

description:
Another solid round of drinks from the Hideout. Came around 8:30 or 9pm on a Friday and was still able to snag a table in the main front room. Liked the creepy stop motion movie that was playing.

Our Hideout cocktails, each $10: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dalva-san-francisco?select=JbS2ITV8vOaLa0pwdUVpTQ#JbS2ITV8vOaLa0pwdUVpTQ

Hideout cocktail menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dalva-san-francisco?select=JbS2ITV8vOaLa0pwdUVpTQ#MuroSofGr21g9zhWtKdDZA

* Disparaging remark - 3.5 stars
(gin, lemon, apricot, egg white & bitter lemon. $10)
Pretty good flavor, a little on the strong side for me (I prefer drinks where the alcohol flavor is more covered - hence not getting this one).

* Oaxacan - 3 stars
(mezcal, etc)
Even stronger, heavier, and a good smoky flavor! Not the fave at the table, but also not quite my style.

* 16th Street Swizzle - 4 stars
(Jamaican rum, lime, honey, orgeat & ginger shrub)
Refreshing, strong ginger - definitely a surprising little kick in flavor. A little on the strong side but still worked well.

I do have to say the bartender wasn't super helpful - I did my usual "I like something light & refreshing, maybe spicy or with ginger is good," and said I was between the Gin & Celbry Tonic and the 16th Street Swizzle. He said I wouldn't be able to taste the gin in the first one (a plus for me), then started talking about making me a strong ginger-flavored Dark & Stormy, but I wanted a cocktail from their menu and he just shrugged and asked what I wanted, so I just went with the 16th Street (felt like something ginger-y). I just personally prefer a bartender who can give me a little more direction within the cocktail menu.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I love that Dalva is cool and low key. I stumbled upon this place on a Saturday afternoon while waiting for a premiere at the next door Roxie theater. Grabbed a beer and never looked back. Ended up staying for hours, chatting with a friend and watching Salem's Lot (Stephen King). Apparently, they have a projector that they use to show old scifi and horror films.

Hideout (a bar inside the bar located in the back room) is also nice. And though I can't vouch for the bartender's recommended craft cocktails, I can say that the ambiance is pretty great. It's quite dim and sketchy-looking from a distance, but it makes for a cozy and intimate venue.  

Cons: Place is very cramped and CASH ONLY
author: Jasmin H.

description: This place had a nice selection of drinks and a cool vibe. You have high bar stools for each table and there's a "Hideaway" in the back. Is that where the karaoke happens? I didn't check it out but may have to! A nice chill place to head with friends for some nice booze and some good ol' chatting away. It wasn't busy when we went and had a huge open space. I can see it filling up on the weekends though. We went on an early Sunday afternoon. It was a chill spot we needed!
author: Natalie M.

description:
This is a cool place to hang out, and it feels super chill and divey. It's down the street from the 16th/Mission BART station, so bonus points! The bartenders are always very friendly and attentive. It's not usually too busy here, which is another reason why I like Dalva.

Minus one star because the cocktails (each $9) are pretty weak. I was especially disappointed by the El Diablo that has tequila, lemon, ginger, cassis, and soda. I could hardly taste the tequila. They have fun selections though. My favorite is the Bee's Knees which has gin, lemon, and honey. They have a bunch of beers on tap from Moonlight Brewery, which it turns out I'm not a fan of. The IPA tasted more sweet and fruity than hoppy, and the Death & Taxes Lager tasted like death.

Minus another star because they pretty much only make the cocktails listed on their menu. I asked for various drinks that contained mint or something spicy, but they said they don't have the ingredients to make those. You can always go to the bar in the other room called Hideout. Just wanted to note my disappointment.

Dalva is CASH ONLY so keep that in mind, too.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Dalva is one of my favorite bars in the Mission.The best part about Dalva is that it's two bars in one. The Hideout is the bar within Dalva. They serve the most amazing cocktails I've ever had in my life. Other Mission bars might be more trendy like Trick Dog and ABV, and they do have awesome cocktails. However, my local recommendation is definitely The Hideout.

The front bar (Dalva proper) takes credit cards but The Hideout only takes cash. There is an ATM by the bathrooms if you need one. You can go straight back to The Hideout and ask for a menu and choose your new favorite cocktail (I have faith you will be returning, lol). Their menu consistently changes but they will always make old menu drinks if you fell in love. My favorite drink ever is the Grapefruit Soda, which ironically has zero grapefruit in it besides the garnish, but tastes like the freshest grapefruit you've had in your life (with a touch of vodka, of course). It is SO GOOD. Watch out though, like all of their drinks they are pretty strong.

Ambiance: perfect for a first date or a GNO. The lighting is dim but not dark and it's not too loud at all so you can have a nice conversation. It's 50/50 on getting a table. High turnover but low amount of seating. All of the bartenders are brilliant and very nice and prompt. 

This is a great spot to go before or after dinner at one of the delicious spots around the area like Monk's Kettle or Lers Ros.
author: Juliet S.

description:
I've walked past Dalva a couple times but never thought about going in. It looks very cramped and long, and I'm not trying to involve myself in that. Then when my chef friend said that there's a secret bar in the back, the Hideout, that offers craft cocktails and a cozy atmosphere, I rallied my girlfriends and we headed over on Friday night.

Dalva was exactly what I expected, so we happily made our way back to the Hideout. It was small back there too, but I liked the intimate feel of it. We all ordered the drink of the evening, which, I of course can't remember the name since we glugged a couple bottles of wine with dinner, but it was basically a fancy, straight up Old Fashioned in a small wine glass. Very strong, with an orange finish. I got to sit and chat with my friend about life and boys before we headed out to Toronado to meet the rest of our crew. Very cool spot, I highly recommend checking it out.
author: Crystal C.

description:
The only bad thing about this place is there are so many delicious drinks you would be floored if you tried them all.

Top favorites?
(1) Moscow Mule
(2) Manhattan
(3) Sangria

I personally love the hideout upstairs but the people watching is better in the front. if you are skillful enough to nab a seat under the stairs, that's my favorite. 

only negative part of this place, people here more than anywhere else I go in the mission try to claim entire tables and extra chairs with the "my friends will be right back" line.  

... yet no one ever shows up.

I guess we all know why you don't have any friends.

..so fifth grade.
author: Mike V.

description: Do you like your liquor served with a complementary chaser of ignorance and stupidity? If so the Dalva is your bar!!! Bad hosts and stupid doormen are just the start. Shitty drinks and douchie patrons await you inside. Its the Michael Phelps of disappointment. Stay away.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Dalva is a cool-ish little dive in the Mission. They have two rooms, the back one called "The Hideout", which features pricier cocktails and a slightly sexier, more romantic ambiance. This would be a good spot to bring that special someone, get shitfaced, and cuddle in the corner, snuggled up in one of the booths. 

Their Sunday night karaoke is a really good time. Jose the KJ kept us entertained, even picking random songs and handing us the mic on the fly. 

The bartenders tend to be a little on the surly side, so be prepared to wait a long time for your drink, and don't expect a smile or a thank you. A couple of times, I've waited at the bar for 5 minutes, and no bartender was to be found anywhere. I went to the back room, and the same thing happened. Where did they all go?! 

They only have one unisex restroom stall, so don't wait too long to relieve yourself.
author: Brandi W.

description:
When we set out to plan our Mad Men and Manhattans party, we wanted to pick a bar that can mix a pretty classy cocktail and Dalva fit the bill. Costumes, cocktails and great company. This is not only a fun bar, but a great place to throw a little party. 

The Lovely Ms. MK "The Hotness" and I put on the unofficial yelp event, but she made all the arrangements, booking the top room in the Hideout. The room is small, but fit our group of almost 25 people. It is a bit hot up there, but the space was all ours.

We ordered drinks from the bar, Black Manhattans, while watching the Bartenders mix them up. I was impressed by the huge collection of bitters, booze and items in which to make old school and custom cocktails. 

Dalva will always be a favorite of mine, for the cocktails I've had and the ones I have yet to try.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
A glorious Mission watering hole in the wall, with another hole in the wall inside. Good for a beer and to hang out, you can pop into the hideout if you want a fancy and excellent cocktail. They also let you bring food in and eat at the tall tables with your beverage of choice, which I appreciate.

Watched the second half of a world cup game here, would have been perfect if the sky light hadn't made the screen half visible.
author: Tasha D.

description: Very cool place. Just stopped on for a quick drink while waiting for a reservation elsewhere but will definitely be back to enjoy more. Love the ambience and style of this place.
author: Karen G.

description: I adore this bar.  The HideOut, in the back, particularly.  Cash only.  Tiny space.  Amazing drinks.  My favorite bar in the Mission, hands down.
author: Sarah F.

description: Trying to go there on my 38th birthday (not for the first time) and they would not let me in. Have been there before and my German ID had not been a problem. Did the law change? Been here for a year and no other place had issue. Even the same place before or places on the same street. Not elsewhere.
author: Nina D.

description: This has been my favorite bar for several years.  The Hideout has a chill vibe, music, and people.  David is the best, and every time I've gone, he's introduced me to a new scotch or carved ice out of a giant special ice block or performed some other kind of bar craft.  The other bartenders are also great.  I don't know if Whiskey in Church is still made here, since you can now order it across the street at ABV (also amazing), but if you can try one, it's SO GOOD.  They always have something new going on in the back menu, but the cocktail flavor combinations are always innovative and delicious.
author: Selene W.

description: The review is for hideout in the back.  The bar is cute (if a bit too dark even for a date situation). It's cash based primarily.  Be forewarned. The staff, especially on weeknights, is extremely rude and barely available.
author: Sri B.

description:
Czech it out.

Awesome beers for an impressive $5 price served by a friendly and attentive bartender: http://www.beeradvocate.com/beer/profile/763/22173/

Cozy little upstairs area perfect for getting to know your drink and the other person: http://www.urbandaddy.com/sfo/nightlife/8454/The_Hideout_at_Dalva_A_Speakeasy_Inside_a_Mission_Dive_San_Francisco_SFO_Mission_Dolores_Bar

Four years after my first review the only thing that has changed is adding two more deserved and overdue stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
If you're looking for a chill, better than divey, but not fancy place, this is perfect. It's not overbearingly crowded and not deserted either. 

The bartenders take great care in making your cocktails, and they make a mean old fashioned!

Nice date place.
author: Angela L.

description:
Excellent bar on a weeknight. Not too crowded; very chill place where you can still talk. Bartenders in the front and also in the Hideout have been very friendly and approachable. They knew what to recommend.

Had the: (in Dalva)
- Boulevardier: sweet upfront with a surprisingly bitter aftertaste, very addicting

Also had: (in the Hideout)
- Altered State: my new favorite; do not be deceived by its transparency - it's smoky, complex, and beautiful
- Gin & Celery Tonic: total thirst quencher, very refreshing and good use of celery bitters 

Can't wait to be back! Reasonably priced.
author: Camie K.

description:
I'm a fan of any good dive bar. The drinks are solid, fairly priced and well-executed.

Now, the Hideout is a whole other story: it's got low ceilings, it's perpetually crowded, the drinks come out slow as molasses, and it's always too hot. I hate it. People love it because of its hidden nature, but I personally could do without it. If people insist in going in back, I order all my drinks in front.
author: Harley C.

description:
Very relaxed dive bar pretty much defining the Mission. Downer is the creepy clock art on the main wall. Seriously, that thing is script for a possessed demon child's drawing. They also play some random old movie on the screen too, which I guess only adds to the hipster vibe. 

Drinks here are really weak but they are $9, so they are a bit cheaper than other places in the Mission. 

There's another bar with fancier cocktails in the back called Hideout. This place is incredibly crowded though so have fun waiting in line. 

Also, cash only!u
author: Winnie T.

description:
I'm not from the area and went to meet a friend there. Woman bartender wasn't friendly in the back. She said I needed to go to the front for wine, so I did. I received my wine in a cocktail glass, weird. The bartender said "we aren't a wine bar" when I asked if they had a wine glass. 

I understand you're not a wine bar but rather a specialty cocktail place. However, wine is clearly available so why not have a few glasses. Make me feel at least a little bit classy ;) 

Anyways, this place overall was pretty cool. The ambiance was nice and if you like specialty cocktails-that is what they have. 

Cheers!
author: LiL R.

description:
Go to the hideout bar in the back. It's dark and romantic.

David is a true mixologist, he will make all of your fancy cocktail dreams come true. If you're  there on a slower night just tell him your fav drinks and he will mix up something amazing. I am so impressed with his skill, he made me the best drink I have ever had! I'm still thinking about that pink tart frothiness that gave me a great buzz! 

Thanks for a great experience David, we will be coming back to visit all the way from seattle whenever we can!
author: Kassi K.

description:
Don't sell someone a drink if you cant let him finish it in peace! 
We arrived for last call, +-5 minutes later they kicked everyone out (was not even 2) and been pretty aggressive and rude about it.
author: Dor L.

description:
Great Selection of Draft Beers for $5 during happy hour, maybe that's their standard price? I didn't try their cocktails but I believe that's what everyone is raving about so a must try next time!

The place is dark, great small back area for groups and you can bring in outside food! 

Overall Thoughts

Definitely would come back to see why Dalva has so many great reviews
author: Eddie W.

description:
Is it a dive bar? Or is it upscale? Is it creepy? Or is it sexy? I dunno but we were fucking mesmerized by the silent movies on the big screen. Beer prices are solid. We stuck to local beers which the bartender knew all about. The dark ambiance was very intriguing.

Drinks: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Location: 4/5
author: Sonya A.

description:
My first thought upon entering the bar: Hmmm, stuffed ferrets and quails are interesting choices for wall decor.

This funky bar is a long hallway that is more of a dive than anything else. It is unremarkable but for the cocktails (and dead animals), which are expertly done and delicious (the cocktails, not the dead animals). The bartender is a dead ringer for Mitch from Dazed and Confused, appropriately advanced in age. He's a serious mixologist and will help you decide what to drink if you get there early enough.

The "speakeasy" in the back doesn't open until 7pm, post happy-hour, which is 5-7pm. So if you're in the mood to sit on a stool and drink a brew while Mission hipsters stroll by the window in tight pants, Dalva is as good a spot as any.
author: Ray J.

description: Great, reliable dive bar that serves solid drinks with friendly, quick, cash-only service with plenty of high top tables that makes expanding your group to those who can stand up.
author: Regina D.

description:
Hideout, the craft cocktail bar in the back room of Dalva, is outstanding.  The ambience is nicely precious-- Low benches, leather, and candlelight; one small bar, one master bartender, working like an artist with a messy mise en place.  It was a little too loud for a group of five, and we took our cocktails to one of the many spacious tables in Dalva itself.

The cocktails were the best I've had West of the Violet Hour in Chicago.  The House Whiskey Cocktail, was some kind of surprisingly complex, easy-drinking boozy cocktail with bourbon, maraschino, bitters, etc.; the bourbon mule was pleasant and refreshing but a little safe; Autumn in Italy was a mix of apple brandy and bitter italian liqueurs that was quite complex, for an apple drink; a gin & amaro drink and a frothy gin sour were well done but a little safe.  All in all it was an impressive array of solid cocktails with no true duds.  

But a cocktail bar is ultimately judged by its best work, and it was outstanding.  Hideout has done the impossible, produce a delicious cocktail made with fernet branca (mixed with sweet vermouth and gran classico, apparently).  It was astonishingly crisp and bracing, yet pleasant.  But the hands-down winner of the night was a gin and celery cocktail that was fresh, herbal, clean, and addictive.  Seriously, celery is the best thing to happen gin since tonic.
author: William B.

description:
Dalva and places similar to this is the biggest reason why I "love" San Francisco. I passed from Dalva's street probably 100+ times and have not realized this hidden gem until a few weeks ago. 

It's great for a first date and trying out cocktails in the hideout. It's generally not that crowded and noisy so if you are looking for a place that you can actually "talk" to the people, Dalva is probably your best bet around Mission.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
This place is okay. 
Cash only. ATM inside.
Good vibe, okay crowd, great drinks and fast service.
Definitely stop by when you're on 16th.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Liked Dalva, but loved the secret bar in the back, Hideout, even more.  The latter boasts some serious cocktails- the type that involves citrus rinds, bitters you've never heard of, and impeccably square ice cubes; all measured out and shaken to perfection.  Spendy, but quite delicious.  

For a date-night in the Mission, I say class it up with a couple of drinks at Hideout, and then head up front for the cheaper but still tasty, easier-on-the-wallet stuff.  

Fun times at Dalva.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Venue: Dive bar in the front, cramped speakeasy in the back. It's pretty grungy and loud, but at least the drinks ain't bad.

Drinks - Bar in the front serves mostly beer and simple cocktails, while the bar in the back serves more sophisticated/unique cocktails. Red Ruby went down easy.
author: Katrina L.

description: Cheap drinks and good location. Never tried the bar up in back, maybe that is for a certain time of the night.
author: Kevin S.

description:
DALVA BAR CLOSES ROXIE ON SUNDAY NIGHTS

Well, not literally.  But Dalva's Sunday night karaoke makes it impossible to enjoy films at the Roxie Theatre next door.  If you prefer films in the original version, without a backdrop of drunk monkeys howling through the wall, avoid the Roxie on Sunday night.  And stay away from Dalva, the cause of the din.  They don't deserve your business.

Dalva is a dive bar gone upscale and pricey.  It's nothing special, really.   By contrast, the Roxie is special.  If you love film, it's a gem, screening independent and foreign films that nobody else bothers with any more.  But if you love film, you might as well assume the Roxie is closed on Sunday nights.  Dalva's loud karaoke makes it nearly impossible to enjoy any film in which silence is part of the oeuvre.  And management simply doesn't care.  Maybe they think that the Roxie screens mainstream action films, with a strong soundtrack, full of helicopters, explosions, revving motors, gunshots and yelling, so that patrons wouldn't notice the din from the drunk monkeys in the dive next door.  But that's not what the Roxie screens.  :-(

To be clear, Dalva doesn't actually close the Roxie on Sunday nights.  But its insensitivity drives business from one of the last independent film houses in San Francisco.  If you love film, or if you just want to make a statement for neighborhood civility, don't patronize Dalva.  There are other dive bars in the neighborhood.  But there's only one Roxie, and Dalva makes it impossible for them to operate one night out of seven.  Dalva will do anything (karaoke?!) to attract business on a slow Sunday.  As such, it doesn't deserve your business on any night.  Go elsewhere.
author: Paul S.

description: This is a review of the Hideout, inside Dalva at the back. It's a cozy little bar with excellent cocktails. It has about 8 seats at the bar and a few two-person tables .
author: Gabe B.

description: This bar is long, they have a great friendly crowd, the drinks are great, they have some cool IPA's,   They have another lil bar connected to the place towards the bathrooms.  This place is pretty rocking and they have some great karaoke on Sundays.
author: Luke S.

description:
A kick of a bar. Every bar in SF has its gimmicks -- this bar's got two.

First, aside from the standard bar setup, with tables in the back and a smattering of two-seaters along the side (kinda like Brass Tacks) they have an extra "cocktail" bar in the back. It's smaller, more crowded, and exciting -- sorta like a western speakeasy. A few nice drinks there, and a real choice selection of beers. We walked in as the crowd broke out in a "Happy Birthday" serenade for... who knows? But get her a drink.

Second, there are campy scifi movies playing overhead in the back of the main section. Perhaps campy is not quite the word. More like train wrecks without trains. Makes for an interesting talking point, should it come to that :D but it justifies the dark setting.

So -- great for a drink of twos or fours. Might be hard of hearing beyond that.

Cocktails in the back were 12 a piece, and the craft beers were around 8.
author: Christophe C.

description: So I'll be honest that I've never sat at Dalva proper, but I have been to the Hideout several times. The Hideout sits at the back of Dalva, once you make your way past the bar and find the doorway leading to it. That's pretty cool in itself. The drinks at the Hideout are some of the best I've had in SF. You can see the detail that goes into each one and the skill of the bartenders. The drinks tend to stay away from sweet flavors, but there's an option for every preference. Noise level is low, which is always a plus. Pricey as any trendy Mission bar.
author: Irina P.

description:
I was at Dalva on a Friday night a few weekends ago and had a terrible experience. I was carrying two drinks back to a group of friends and had some guy unzip my purse and steal my phone. I turned around and made eye contact with him before he walked upstairs. Once I realized what had happened about 30 seconds later, I found him with a group of friends and approached him. He denied taking my phone and laughed at me for accusing him. 

I talked to the bouncer to see if he was able to help and he told me that the guys were "nicely dressed" and he didn't think that they were capable of taking my phone right out of my bag. Not only was he zero help, but he also made me feel completely unsafe and ridiculous for accusing the guy upstairs. I downloaded the find my phone app on my boyfriends phone and it confirmed that my device was in the building. I was very disappointed about how the situation was handled and I would never go back to this bar. I would also strongly deter anyone thinking about going there, unless you are in the market to be a victim of theft and then laughed at when trying to recover your stuff.
author: Terri R.

description: Cute secret not so secret back room and I love the crushed ice gin drink!
author: Karen T.

description: Perty good drinks/nice happy hour spot in the Mission. I will put it on my list of highlight Mission dive bars to frequent...
author: Mel G.

description:
There's not an option for "0 stars", but if there was, I'm all for it in rating Dalva. Some friends and I were bar hopping in the mission. The birthday boy of or group wanted to hop over to this bar. We were asked to show our I.D.'s, the usual upon entering any bar. Good music was playing, the crowd and ambiance was pretty chill. We had a few drinks from previous bars so we were just enjoying the scene and music. It was a cool bar.  However, the moment four of my friends: 3 Filipinos & 1 Saudi, attempted to order drinks the bartender immediately, with no hesitation, responded with a flat out "No". Surprised by his reaction, my friend assumed maybe the bartender didn't have the right alcohol for the drink requested. He asked for a different drink, and like before the bartender responded with a "I can't serve you guys". The bartender asked for IDs. Once he came across my Saudi friend's ID, he said that he didn't recognize the I.D. (Well yeah, he's a foreign exchange student). Convinced that we were all "under-age", even though the bouncer let us in, he refused to offer us drinks. Confused by the bartenders actions, we looked around the room and near the bar to check out our surroundings, and yes, there were more Caucasian individuals than colored Filipinos and Saudis in the bar. We obviously were not the usual "crowd" that came into that bar. Considering that this was a bar in SF, the last thing we wanted this incident to be was an act of racism. However, it definitely felt like it. And it was a feeling that I've never felt while living here in SF until that night. We and our group of friends left that bar immediately after the incident.

Dear bartender with the beard, long  hair & ponytail, all we wanted was a drink. If you had something against us, at least let another bartender serve us; easy as that, dude. 

I've heard good things about this place and was completely turned off and disgusted by this bartenders actions. Watch out for that one, folks; he obviously has a preference in customers.
author: Bel O.

description:
was there last night and ordered 2 cocktails from the A.hole behind the bar...One drink was great the other one was lame = $20...the hideout is NOTHING special and there are so many better options than this place, not sure why the bartenders had an attitude as it was not busy and they had plenty of time to be friendly and provide good service if only they knew how!!!!
F them!
author: bob b.

description: Great place if you're in the mood for a dive bar. Superb service and yummy house snacks. Great neighborhood.
author: Dawn H.

description:
I love wandering into the cocktail room in the back. It's perfect on a slow night for a small, intimate group and the times I've gone there the bartenders are always friendly and quick.  David took care of my friend and I on a not-so-slow wednesday night, concocting some awesome stuff that hit the spot right away after a great dinner. The man is a killer mixologist and the ambiance (in the back) is perfect.

My go to spot if Monk's Kettle is too rowdy and I want to have a conversaton for a change. :D
author: Annie W.

description:
A mixologist's dream!  A bar inside of a bar (the Hideout), this place although hole in the wall is a lot of fun with a very vibrant crowd to go with.

Check out the Hideout in the back of the bar, which has an interesting list of drinks which will have you mesmerized at how the bartenders are making them.

Reasonably priced for SF standards, definitely one of my go to spots when I am in the Pac Northwest.
author: Luke W.

description: Loved the hideout.  Such a different feel than Dalva, so be sure to walk to the back to check out the hideout!  The drinks are great and it's a cool place to chill.  Only issue is that it's a super small space so it gets cramped pretty easily.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Came here after Folsom Street Fair for a drink with two of my friends on a sunday evening. Dark chill interior, nice bartenders, and even a secret bar: the hide out.

The hide out wasn't open yet, so we ordered two rounds of drinks before happy hour ended: two IPAs, two whiskeys, and two gin and tonics = $20 (not incl. tip), which is solid.

Pretty decent beer selection on tap, too!

The hide out is a cool place where they serve craft cocktails. It's small, but cozy and intimate. Great old fashioneds.

Recommend checking it out.
author: Andy J.

description:
I really should come here more often.

It doesn't look that inviting from the outside, kinda dark and sketchy-looking, but it's a really decent place to grab a drink with friends and catch up. As opposed to other places on the block, Dalva is a bit quieter and has a more chill vibe, so it's better spot for conversation. It's also got the whole bar within a bar thing going, so don't forget to walk past the bathrooms in the back and check out the vibe on the other side.

I should go there more often...
author: Madhu P.

description:
Decent bar. 

Was a little disappointed that the bartenders were not interested in doing anything other than their signature list. Drinks were good, but overall the atmosphere was lacking.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
**MR. JACK ROSE GREETED ME GRACIOUSLY HERE**

Luckily, the Parking Gods were with us because we found a space right across the street.

Our birthday friend  hosted a shindig at the *HIDEOUT* upstairs, but we were inclined to order a few drinks downstairs, especially with our 50% off SCOUT MOB coupon.

The bartender didn't know what a Blood and Sand cocktail was, so I told him to make me his favorite drink. He suggested the *JACK ROSE*.

With a few shake and bakes and a $4 price tag, the JACK ROSE drink was simply delicious. Tasted gourmet; like a true craft cocktail.

The JACK ROSE was so good, I ordered 4 more.

And I was truly BUZZING at the end of the evening.

Nice speakeasy feel to this bar. I liked.

RECOMMEND for the Mission.
author: Betty N.

description:
It's very un-missioney. 
And I liked it. 
Bartenders move quickly, always a plus. 
$5 GnT also a plus.
They play 80's music. And when they aren't playing 80's music, they play something I call "Music That Doesn't Suck." 

Gripe: Cash only
Highlight: D&T on tap, the vibe, the music.
author: Emily D.

description: Nice chill bar that we found while walking around between Hayes valley, Castro and the mission. It's a bit of a younger crowd but worth checking out if you are near the area. Bartender made a great sour martini for us, super strong but the best part was it was cheap. One of my favorite new bars in this area!!
author: Matthew M.

description: This review is for Hideout. This is a bar within a bar. This bar is in the back of Dalva and their menu is specialty cocktails. My favorite drink here is the dirty pigeon. I did try the doorman, but it was too strong for my taste. Place does get crowded, but luckily with my eagle eye, I was able to snag a booth just as the group was leaving. The space in Hideout was just too tight. I think if I didn't get a table, I would have left early. No where to put anything. There is an upstairs area, but that night there was a private party. Even then, the space upstairs was even tinier, and there was no bar. Overall, good cocktails, small space. Get here early!
author: Lisa T.

description: Hideout is in the back of Dalva, and lacks windows, so it was pretty warm the whole night. The upstairs looks to be a whole other private area, but if they have a birthday up there you're out of luck. No bar though, so you'll be forced to walk down and mingle with the other non-cool people. Has a great selection of tequila drinks, but didn't really feel the whiskey ones they had. Guess I'm more of a Bourbon guy.  Props to them for knowing how to make "smokey" tequila drinks for the ladies, though. Pliny for over $5 was steep, but the best I could muster (hard to find this anywhere, anyhow). Keep your eyes peeled the whole night...we were able to upgrade our seating arrangements from hovering near the bar to a small corner table to a large booth by the end of the night. Truly was sad to give that up when we left. Bring that cash money too...credit kindly not accepted here.
author: Dan M.

description: The Hideaway was closed and the bartender didn't need to tell me that Gordon's is gin and Rittenhouse is rye.  Otherwise it was alright-nice bar and good cocktails go a long way.
author: Myles L.

description: Drinks arent too pricey which is great. Bartender was quick to serve. Cash only which was a bit of an annoyance, but whatever. Loud music so if you're going here to chill, thats great - but if you're here to chat, might be easier to go somewhere else. There's a neat little bar cave at the back that i like too lol
author: Bianca C.

description:
I stopped by here with some friends to grab drinks and just chill. I've been to Dalva before and I liked it so I suggested this place.

The place has not changed since my last visit. For a Sunday night, it was pretty packed. This may or may not have something to do with the Karaoke they had going on. I never asked but I'm assuming this means that Sundays are karaoke nights. I've never really cared for karaoke, but when you're at a bar listening to other people go up and possibly going up for yourself....it's the best thing EVER. Especially when alcohol is involved.

I ordered a Black & Tan while my friends got a whiskey/coke and a cider drink respectively. I originally wanted a white Russian but they didn't have milk. That's the only downside to this bar....they run out of things a lot. Or don't have it in stock. 

Didn't really faze me though. I enjoyed my drink although I admit that I've had better/prettier versions of the same drink. Plus side to this bar is that the drinks are much cheaper. We all paid around $4 I believe.

Anyway, the best part of this place at the time was karaoke. It's just too damn fun! 

I like Dalva.
author: Sofia R.

description:
OBNOXIOUS, RUDE, ARROGANT - DO NOT SUPPORT THIS TREATMENT

Came pretty late for a last drink to wrap up the evening. Had a nice chat with bartender in back room and ordered some expensive specialty drink. They don't take cards, so I had to go and get cash. I come back, pay, tip him well and get the drinks. 

We sit down, literally have 3 sips from the drinks, then they turn on the lights and ask us to move to the front bar. It is 1.37 am and they supposedly close at 2 am. 

I sit down on a bar stool with full drink and immediately 2 guys come up to my face and starts yelling: "COME ON, GET OUT!" in a super aggressive tone. I asked them in the calmest and most polite tone possible -- because I was really concerned that I would get beat up -- if we could just finish our drinks quickly and what time they were actually closing. They alternated between "HAVE YOU EVER BEEN TO A BAR IN SF?" and "GET THE FUCK OUT". I could also see my friend who was now outside being pushed by the door man as he wanted to come back in to grab his stuff, which was still with me. 

This is the most OBNOXIOUS, RUDE, AGGRESSIVE and ARROGANT attitude I've experienced in SF -- and completely unnecessary.
author: Anna S.

description:
Sunday karaoke! [Is it even still on Sundays?]

Tiny place, but good drinks and the Hideout in the back is a hidden treasure - check it out!
author: Stephani C.

description:
This was my first experience at a dive bar. A couple of locals that lived in the neighborhood took us to this place. They highly recommended it, and I thought it was pretty cool. We went here on Halloween, although very few people were dressed up, there were some that came in. 

The place was crowded, and there weren't many places to sit. I liked that there was sort of a ledge where people could stand on the stairs and below the wooden divider. It made the bar seem bigger than it actually was, and allowed our group to split up and mingle with different people that we came with.

Crowd: I'm not sure about the crowd, I mostly stuck with my group of people.

Drink: I had the Moscow Mule. It was quite delicious. :)

I would come back again, but would also like to explore other places in the area.
author: Christina L.

description:
Dalva is a good bar, but it's kind of like if they started making chocolate bar wrappers out of cheap gum: I appreciate the attention to detail on the exterior, but I'm probably just going to disregard it and go right for the prize wrapped inside. In this case, that prize is The Hideout. The best thing I have to say about Dalva is that the layout is a nice, expeditious straight line between the entrance to the building and what I actually care about. 

The Hideout, as anyone reading this no doubt knows, is (one of) THE places to get snooty artisanal cocktails from mustachioed bartenders who on the best days are wonderful gentleman-scholars about the art of getting customers fucked up for money and on the worst days ignore me in favor of staring down the top of every girl who walks by while mainlining shots of whiskey. If you beat the crowd and get a table for you and your friends (especially in the loft area up top), the Hideout is generally a lot of fun as long as you're the type of person who appreciates that they will garnish things with blood orange peel or a splash of rosemary-infused gin. Since I am that person, I think this place is amazing. If you are looking for a place to get some dollar drafts and chill with your bros, you might want to try elsewhere.

Also, this place is not "divey" in the most important sense of the word: the price. It's certainly dark and cramped, but you'd best expect to shell out if you want something interesting, so come prepared to spend a little more than you would otherwise.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
This place was great! Had dinner around the corner and popped into the Hideout for a night cap. 

Drinks were amazing, the bar tenders were attentive, quick and masters of their craft.

Can't wait to take new friends here!
author: Nick W.

description:
Long time customer, but new fan.  The Hideout backroom "secret" fancy bar is a real winner.  The rest of the place is nice and a good normal bar, but cocktail nerds will love the back room.

It's small and you'll wait 10 min for a cocktail, but it's so worth it.  And at similar high quality bars the time for prep is similar in my experience.  If you just want a pint glass of gin and tonic, stick to the front room.

Put your trust in the bar tender, I started to say something about liking Bourbon in a savory preparation and he stopped me, said "savory, you have to try my celery cocktail" and then went into a flurry of activity.

The drink was incredible, maybe I'd call it a celery gin fizz?  Not sure what it had in it, but I want another.
author: Patrick S.

description: They don't have diet soda here but the ambiance is fantastic. My friend wanted a glass of milk which they didn't have either. (I swear we were drinking alcohol too!) Service can be slow at times. Tried some of their cocktails but I didn't like any of them. Will probably be back just because its so close to bart.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
I wish I could close my eyes as I walk though Dalva and just open them when I get to the Hideout. But then I'd probably run into a lot of tables and hipsters.

The Hideout is my secret "bar inside a bar," although by now it's no secret. Their grapefruit soda cocktail is on 7x7's 100 Drinks To Try Before You Die: it's fantastic. Tastes just like grapefruit soda but has all the kick of a good cocktail.

The bar area of Hideout gets crowded quickly and the music is always a little too loud, so I try to get up to the lofted area for a seat. It's dark and loud and a total dive, but the only dive bar I actually like. A lot.
author: Emilia S.

description:
A fun, low key bar to chill out in the Mission, Dalva is a wonderful place to catch up with friends over many libations. 

The charm of the bar isn't just confined to the decor or crowd. I love the random 70s movies that play in the background. There are few things more fun than filling in your own dialog to the action. 

Dalva has a great variety of beers on tap and at pretty fair prices too. I really liked the Reality Czech that they had on tap. It's a really easy to drink Pilsner and while hard to find, was one of Dalva's numerous taps. 

Dalva strikes a fine balance in the Mission - not too divey, not too classy, not too hipster, not too proper. All in all, just a pretty great bar.
author: Jon L.

description:
Review of the Hideout:

If I'm going to pay $10-11 for a cocktail, I certainly appreciate it if the bartender crafts it with care.  When we ordered one of their specialty cocktails, the Bourbon Mule, our bartender made it, tasted it, decided it wasn't perfect, and immediately tossed it and started over again.  When we ordered a standard cocktail, a Rob Roy, he asked if he could make something a bit more creative instead, and presented us with a similar and delicious drink using homemade coffee bitters.  Hmm, I wonder if I can order off menu from now on...
author: Beatrice W.

description: The holiday cheer has officially started! Bourbon, Campari, maple, egg, allspice, cream, and coffee bitters. Ho ho ho!
author: Miss H.

description:
I normally love The Hideout. It's a great spot for good drinks. Except for last night. 

The Mission is known for our surly bartenders. It's one of the things I've grown to love about my neighborhood. But when the bartender, let's call him Napoleon, is SO intoxicated that he drops and breaks a full bottle of liquor (which I'm sure the owner is happy about), doesn't understand your order, gives you attitude for ordering shots (when he and his buddies were taking round after round of shots) it doesn't entice you back. 

I'm not sure who he was showing off for - the guy he was training? his friend? but we weren't impressed.
author: Anne H.

description:
So very San Francisco. So very chill. So very great to hide out in.

I have loved this bar for years, especially their back room and Friday night reminded me of that. The cocktails back there are *fab* if that's your thing - as are the bartenders.

Cheers to Dalva - always a great night there.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Truly one of my favorite dive bars in the city! 

Let me caution, it is definitely not a place to party. Surprisingly, it's a chill spot for conversation amidst all the hustle and bustle of the Mission District night life. The front area sports a jukebox and long bar...typical so far, right? Now go to the back, the "Hideout." Here you can get top shelf liquor or a custom cocktail. Last time I came, I tried a $30 rum that tasted like vanilla fire. There's even a little nook upstairs in the back, that they occasionally block off for private parties.  Here's the perfect place to catch up with that friend you haven't seen in ages.

Oh and cash only ;) Enjoy!
author: Cassie C.

description:
The Hideout, which is located in the back of Dalva, is one of my favorite little dive bars in the city. They've always got amazing music going, it's small, dark (with red lights), intimate and cozy and the cocktails are to DIE for. 

The cocktails are so fancy, and I love me a fancy cocktail! They are made very strong with dashes of this and bits of that. They're really amazing and I love watching the bartenders making the drinks.

Cash only, a bit on the expensive side (about $10 for one cocktail) but definitely a great atmosphere and experience. Love the Hideout!
author: Naomi T.

description:
I am not a huge fan of divey places, I don't like the grunge factor of the Mission and no, I don't think it adds "character" whatever the eff that is.  Hipsters are more the (deserving) targets of snide remarks in my world.  That said, I do occasionally find myself in the heart of hipster central SF and when I do, I always make a stop at Dalva.  

Pretty great drinks in the hideout and the music is not bad, if too eclectic. They make a great aviation cocktail and it's not toooo hipstery or crowded (i.e. elbo room)
author: Robert B.

description:
This is a sexy type Mission bar for sure! Dim lighting, a cool back area, and a movie screen that plays random stuff. Drinks seemed to be be competitively priced, I guess, I think. Did I pay for any? I don't think I did but it didn't seem like it was too steep.
There's a cool mix of people hanging here, I liked it, I'd go back. Friendly bar tender.
author: Lizzy M.

description:
I came here for book club on a Sunday night but the place was still packed! 

(+)
- Great ambiance, inviting and cozy
- Nice room upstairs for private parties
- 2 bars that wrap around the interior and make it super easy to get served
- The bartenders are really nice and knowledgeable
- They have CIDERS!!! Anthem was on tap when I was there and they had Tieton in a bottle but it was sold out. :(

(-)
- Might just be a bit noisy so intimate conversation should not be an expectation. I think they were playing music also which made it difficult to hear people. 

Will definitely go back. Nice little night spot in Mission.
author: Jenn M.

description:
I stopped in last weekend for cocktails with a few friends, and I thoroughly enjoyed myself. I found myself particularly amused while watching the bartender prepare our drinks. My friend had ordered a drink that required some moderately-involved preparation (don't recall what the drink was, I'm afraid), and I became completely entranced watching it come to life. The bartender's movements were so mesmerizingly precise and deliberate, each movement terminating with a sensual flourish -a whiff of the liquor, or a taste of an ice chip.

In fact, the first thing that popped into my head while watching this was that scene from Love Actually where Rowan Atkinson (aka Mr. Bean) is gift-wrapping a necklace. The drink's preparation was similarly over-the-top in the most wonderful and amusing way. If you haven't seen the film, this clip captures the moment. Watch it. No really, I insist. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cfNzZre-sIU

Oh yeah, my whiskey sour was pretty good, too.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I can't believe I lived a few blocks away for over a year and I never stopped at Dalva.

The sign and the glance in aren't terribly flattering, but once you get in the surroundings are surprisingly intimate (note: I came in on Election Night / Day of the Dead, so perhaps the bar gets louder with more of a crowd).

The service was awesome.  Our bartender was extremely friendly, and offered to talk us through the bar's featured cocktails (and even suggested a couple of his own concoctions if we weren't totally sold).

Prices are just north of dive bar, which is awesome given that the drink and service quality is well north of dive.

I'd definitely head back to Dalva with friends.
author: Bill H.

description:
Me likey Dalva, it walks the line of a chill feel dive feel but classy staff and surroundings of a lounge. Good servers and beer like a dive, nice space with movies on the wall like a lounge.

A good mix, get what I'm saying? Too many times, specifically in the Mission, it's one way or the other. I'm swanked out like a mofo or standing in urine at some dive bathroom. Dalva takes the best of both worlds and makes it happen.

Next time you got a mix of friends with different preferences, keep Dalva out there as an option. Works for everyone.
author: Justin N.

description:
Pluses: 
1) Dark, so much so that you can't see your date. It makes it mysterious...
2) Attentive, respectable bartenders
Beers: Nice draft selection with some rarer brews
Cocktails: I've only had one and I'm not exactly a cocktail guru, so I'll just say "thumbs up."
Decor: Taxidermy + 80s cult films. Not too stuffy, not too grimy. 
Crowd: People who like this type of place.
author: Heidi H.

description:
Great place to grab a drink before and/or after your going to a movie at the Roxie (next door on both sides!) 

I love the drinks on their menu! My favorite is the one withcucumber jalapeno tequila! I can't think of the name, but it is a fantastic drink! I love tequila, but I am not so into sweat and sour and this drink is the answer!

In the back of the bar there is a space called the Hideout, which is open Monday-Saturday. There is a second bar back there and that is where they make the ultra fancy drinks. Just ask for something special and you will get it. They make good drinks up front too, but the front bar is busier and louder than the back and Hideout bar specializes in more upscale drinking. So you get both in the SAME bar! Pretty fantastic. 

Sundays is a rocking karaoke night. There is an amazing list of songs and the sound is surprisingly good--the host brings in his own sound system that is tailored to karaoke. There are 4 microphones and screens everywhere you turn, including a big projection screen.
author: Paul d.

description: At least they give free goldfish crackers but their drinks.  They're alright nothing special.
author: Vince S.

description:
Dalva is kind of under the radar. It's easy to miss if you aren't paying attention and the sign out front is unassuming and not much of a representation of what is nicely tucked inside.

Dalva is a great place to grab a well-made artisan cocktail with some great dance tunes. The bar feels a bit crowded in the front and definitely has a younger feel in the front, but make sure to make the walk back to the back room/bar where it is a bit more intimate and the bar tenders tend to have a bit more focus on the customers.

The service is awesome and my old-fashioned was perfectly made with a well balanced bourbon and the most important part, a GIANT ICE CUBE, that won't melt fast to water down the drink.

Dalva is a solid drink spot - I'll be sure to be back.
author: Justin O.

description:
I thought Dalva/Hideout was awesome! I'd never been here before so we decided to decided to check it out the other night.

What a cool spot in the Mission! I love the Hideout in the back - feels private and is so easy to get drinks and just have good conversations with people. Such a good place to relax and enjoy your drinks. They have an interesting cocktail list - make sure you you wisely choose one that you'll enjoy! :)
author: Priya G.

description: I give 5 stars because Dave the bartender was throughly enjoyable to talk to and introduced me to my new favorite drink even tho I don't remember what it's called. Yay bourbon! If it wasn't for him I'd give 4 stars because it was super duper dark in the hideout in back.
author: Bevin H.

description:
Came here on a Monday night.  If you're a fan of whisky, ask for the Derby. 

Schmwowwww
author: Jenny M.

description:
The drinks here are great. Those alone I'd give a 4.5 stars. I can ask for a Bee's Knees and they know what I'm taking about and how to properly prepare it. 

The atmosphere was meh. Like a 2-3. 

Come here to grab a few good drinks then hop to the next spot if you can still walk well.
author: George K.

description: We actually went to the secret bar, The Hideout, in the back of Dalva. Cozy environment with a tiny bar and really fun cocktails. Pretty cool experience. The bartenders are friendly and make drinks with a flair. Good experience. Multiple tasty cocktails.
author: Zara S.

description:
If you're heading to Dalva, make sure it's to be in the hideout section in the back. The front portion corrals you down a narrow space between the bar and some tables until you reach the only open space, which also happens to be where everyone lines up for the bathroom. Fun times.

The hideout, on the other hand, is chill, and you get access to all top-shelf liquors. I was happy to find they had Lagavulin, except for $17, you'd think you'd get better than what might as well be a 5-to-1 ratio of ice cube to scotch. /shrug

Overall, fair compromise between a loungey bar and a dive.
author: Eddy P.

description:
I used to love going to Dalva & Hideout. Things changed a few days ago when a friend and I went to Dalva and ordered a sailor jerry and coke. SJ is clearly not top shelf. We got charged 16$ for 2 drinks, which seemed steep. We simply asked how much was the drink, in case they had made a mistake and not realized how much money we had given. The annoyed response was, "it's $8 but I should have charged you guys $9 each." WTF?! The bartender then added, "How much do you think I should have charged you?". We were dumbfounded at the attitude and out of spite with the attitude we were like we just wanted to know how much and it's definitely more expensive than it should be. He refunded us $1 for each drink and we were like we don't want it and didn't take the money. It's not that we care about the $, but it was the attitude that was dished out to us when we asked a simple question of how much each drink was. 

I'll still go to the Hideout for its great cocktails, and most of the great reviews are for the inner room. Will definitely pass on the attitude-surcharging dive bar. 

Also it was a watered down drink! In comparison, 1015 Folsom makes a better drink (which I thought was one of the worst places in SF for a drink).
author: Ajesh S.

description: Don't forget to bring your passport, because a foreign drivers license isn't welcome here. Even though this method of identification is accepted at any self-respecting bar, this bar is definitely not among them.
author: Michiel P.

description: Wouldn't take a foreign ID without an accompanying passport, even though our IDs were clearly legitimate and we're well over legal age. What. The. Fuck. Is. This. Shit?!?!
author: Andrew W.

description:
Zomg, how have I not reviewed this place yet??

This review is really for The Hideout, which I adore and am going through withdrawals right now.  But all that shall be remedied this weekend!

My first intro was for a wonderful pahtay put on by the lovely and fabulous MK moons ago.  I brought the Boss with me since he lived quite close.  Others couldn't make it.  That night, I was introduced to their house whiskey cocktails.  It was love at first sip.

They only open up at seven each night, but it's so totally worth it.  The place is small and gets super crowded, so beware of elbow pushing and waiting your turn to order at the bar.  But these guys are pros.  Every minute wait is worth it in the end.
author: Lorrayne L.

description:
Came here with a friend on a Saturday evening. After hours and hours of shopping in the MIssion we needed a break. 

Best way to relax? Grabbing a couple of Bloody Mary's at Dalva.

WTF. I don't even like Bloody Mary's.

These were so good though. MMM.
author: Zam M.

description: It gets kind of crazy downstairs, but you have to go upstairs to the back.  The back room is very intimate and low key with great drinks.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
I had about 20 minutes before my BART train came. That's a perfect amount of time to fire down a cocktail or two. My buddy had been to this place a few times in the past and wanted me to check it out.

We went right by the front bar to the back area called The Hideaway. You know when people say things like, "handmade tortilla" or "handmade clothing?" You think of some nice, old Mexican lady with some dough and that big clampy thingy or some 13 year olds in Thailand with a loom.

When I say handmade cocktail, I think of the guy in the small, dark room in back room of Dalva mixing up adult beverages. The guy makes each beverage with such care, precision and love. It's simply amazing. He mixes the cocktail right up to the line on the measuring jigger not to be skimpy, but to make the flavor of the cocktail *exactly* how it should be. When he's done with the beverage, he takes a quick sip out of it (with the straw, not out of the actual glass) to ensure it's the way it should be. It may take a minute or two extra to get your cocktail, but it's worth the wait.

There's a cool red, little room up the stairs way in the back that is a nice spot to hang and talk some shit with some friends. Such a good spot. While the music is awesome, it isn't super loud, so you can actually hear the people you're talking to.
author: Patrick Z.

description: The environment was really cool, but their special drink just tasted like tequila haha...very strong. Good place to hang out with a few friends.
author: Charles Z.

description:
One of my favorite Mission bars that hasn't has been taken over by the new migration of hipster implants from who-knows-where. Low-key, dark, good selection of beer and spirits, and good bartenders make it a great place to hang with your friends. I usually feel a little overdressed in this typically jeans, t-shirt, and mustache crowd but I don't care if they don't. No judgements.
