The Hideout, Dalva's back bar, is where you'll find me more often sipping Bourbon and Whiskey with friends and strangers alike. Its got a great selection of higher end and rare spirits. The cocktails there look and sound amazing yet I've only had a few sips as I'm a "straight up" kinda guy. Be prepared to do a little standing there if you're not lucky enough to grab one of only 4 tables. There is also an upstairs room that is used for parties and for those who just want to get away from the crowds.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
This is a fun and friendly bar. 

I had an event here and I'd like to personally thank the staff in general as well as Erik and Craig in particular for making this happen.

They have a separate room in the back past the restrooms that you can reserve. I didn't know this and thought I'd reserved the area at the end of the bar. I started getting a little put off by the interlopers until I got a few beers into me and then found out that my group was in the wrong place. I didn't see the back room but I liked the spot we were in so much that I didn't care.

One last thing; these guys know how to treat a person that brings in business.
author: Manny F.

description: The bartender is terrible and overlooked us repeatedly. When I told him about it he was rude and dismissive. I immediately walked out with my friends. I regret tipping him on my first drink.
author: Andy H.

description:
EVERLASTING LIGHT.

At the hideout. It has totally become my regular spot in the Mission and I have ended up here way too many times in the recent past but get me my drink and I can't resist.
author: Raina B.

description:
Dalva is a really wonderful bar. The bartenders are so friendly (especially Breezy - hi Breezy!), they have a great selection of beers, and the basic cocktails are prepared stiff and proper. 

I love going on Sunday nights when KJ Paul is hosting karaoke. The whole place gets packed around 11pm, so be sure to get there by 9 or 10 for a table! The crowd rocks along with the singers, so it's a whole bar experience.

For a real treat, head to the back and check out the fancy cocktails at The Hideout. My favorite bartender David knows his way around a shaker and serves up some of the most delicious cocktails I've ever tasted. He even made me love gin! What a feat :)

So Dalva. And Sunday karaoke with @KJPaul. And The Hideout. Go get some.
author: SisterMable S.

description: Can't say I was a fan. My friends and I went here and we were in the very back also known as the hideout. The room is tiny and way too hot. I ended up not ordering anything because I'm a vodka kind of girl and the drink Manu had nothing with vodka. My friends and I didn't last there very long because the music was so loud we couldn't even hear one another. I probably won't come back here again
author: Miriam G.

description: Stumbled upon this place just bar hoping around the mission. Definitely checkout the back/hideout bar and upstairs area vs the bar by the entrance. Delish old fashion and manhattan- including a huge variety of bitters. Loved the ambiance and had a good vibe on a Friday night, decently priced cocktails.
author: michelle l.

description:
The atmosphere has improved noticeably from my previous review - they still tend to keep the lights very low, but it's got more of a cool vibe, with lots of small red lights and subtle inset-grille lights in the walls, which is pretty cool.  Still quite minimalist in feel - it's certainly not over decorated by any stretch - and they still usually have a movie projected against the back wall.

The beer selection is good, and the bar is usually not too crowded, which is better.  But the best part is the Hideout - basically a whole second bar in the back, tiny, intimate, even darker than the front, but with fantastic high-end cocktails on a revolving menu, and a rotating set of bartenders who get to ply their delicious trade to an appropriately attentive audience.  Seriously - there are all of 6 seats at the mini-bar, with table/bench seating for maybe 10 more people, plus an additional upstairs space that tends to get too warm & stuffy.

The only down side to the Hideout is the volume level - such a small space, with nothing but hard wood surfaces, and as soon as there are more than about 5 people the conversations have to start fighting each other for space.

But other than that minor quibble, it's pretty fantastic.  Plus, it may be the only place left in the city to get Todd Smith to make you cocktails. :)
author: Don H.

description: Smallish bar with three separate areas, all of which have ample seating and space to rest your drinks.  Prices are cheap, drinks are strong, faces are friendly.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Come on ! karaoke here.  Sorry guys no japanese  music.? . well the place is kind of cripy cozy and cooll.  they were a lot of wierd thos like . well what do u expect in 16 th and valencia  any way. drinks  a little expensive even tho its no a high end place. 
 I dont suppose to complain cuz I didnt paid for my drinks.
author: Cesar E.

description:
Terrific for a quick beer while:

a. waiting for the movie to start at the Roxie
b. waiting for a table at Little Star
c. enjoying life
author: Phuong M.

description:
Dalva, I'm pretty sure you're one of my favorite bars on the block.

Right when I walked in there was a couple making out at the bar. What a welcoming entrance! The good thing was that they left enough wiggle room for me to order a drink from the nice bartenders. The place is nice and intimate, almost like a cave of wonders type of lighting. The red candles spread throughout was a nice touch. There's also a screen up above playing obscure cinema for your conversation starting pleasure. Like, "What the...? Are they crucifying that guy? Oh no, it was some dude's crazy dream. Oh shit, no it's not a dream! What the fuck am I watching?" You know, that kind of stuff. A little visual stimulation along with drinks is always a good time. Also, they have a great beer selection. Any place that has Death and Taxes on tap is fine with me.

In the back there's The Hideout. At first we thought it was some sort of exclusive place and thought, "Whoa, a bar within a bar!" That is awesome. They have more of a liquor selection for your refined tastes, also it's a great spot to just hang out with your group of friends without having to move for a crowd of people every second, but that usually happens on the weekend.

This place is always a first stop on the Mission block when it comes to barhopping. Easily accessible by Muni and Bart and just a hop, skip, and a jump away from the other bars in the area. Or maybe you just want to unwind with a nice, cold drink after seeing a movie at the Roxie. Either way, good times are waiting to be had!
author: Leslie K.

description: This place is a dive in the worst possible way. We ordered drinks at the front in 'Dalva'- they were fine nothing special. Unfriendly service. Moved to 'The Hideout' because the music was better. Ordered another round and the drinks were absolutely undrinkable. I don't even have high standards, but we took one sip, put our drinks down on the bar, and left. Thanks but no thanks!
author: Rhian M.

description:
Oh boy was I in for a surprise when I finally made it to that back bar!

There are some mixology geniuses that work that back bar and I have tasted some rare adult libations from far reaches of the globe I never new existed before.  

Their selection of scotch, ryes, bourbons, cognacs and armagnacs isn't encyclopedic but definitely well chosen and varied.  I've had many a  libacious thrill ride here since discovering the place for myself.  Check it out!

I love that word.  Libacious.  Heh.

That should be in the dictionary.
author: Theron L.

description:
stopped in for a drink (ginger ale) after viewing a flick at the roxie...i had to be the oldest patron in this bar of hipsters...i felt pretty hip in my tan dockers and my aloha shirt...yep.. was like the old days....i felt lucky and had a second libation..plenty of action on the street...people with sty cups begging money from the hipsters....the beggars seem more animated at night... they sense profits are to be made in the neon haze....

Ah...The night life...it's my life!!!
author: Brent P.

description: Had such amazing, meticulously prepared, cocktails at Dalva, will check out Hideout the next time!
author: Anupama K.

description: I came here with a bunch of yelpers for a MAD MEN party which was in the HIDEOUT upstairs.  It was pretty crowded and there was bar specifically for the hidehout which was nice. It held maybe 5 seats but there was a sitting area next to it. The bartendars were really cool and attentive. Even though it was really busy they do acknowledge you. They had some delicious and creative drinks like the grapefruit fizz..which didn't even taste like a grapefruit soda. I am not a fan of grapefruit but this was delicious. The music was super loud in the main bar and they had a big screen with something playing. I didn't really pay much attention to see if it was a movie or music videos. They also have a juke box which is always a plus in my book! Drinks were a bit pricey but thats the price you pay to be different.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description:
Sometimes a good cocktail is worth the wait.  And I'm not talking about waiting in a sea of people because the bartender ignores everyone except for the hottest skirt at the bar.  I'm talking about waiting at a lowly dive bar while a bartender carefully crafts a fine drink.

Skip the front main bar - the Hideout in the back is the place to be for drinks and a dark cozy corner to hang with friends.  The bartenders take forever to make the drinks - looking for specific ingredients and running back to the stock room to get something that's missing.  Needless to say, your top shelf drink won't have some cheap liquor or mixer substitute.  The special cocktail menu drinks are a bit pricey, but be adventurous, and trust the bartender.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I used to go here quite a bit when I lived in the Mission.  I remember they were the only place in town where you could get a mint julep (and drink it while shivering in the fog).  I was pleased to see that it was just as cool as I remembered -- perhaps even better.

The back/upstairs Hideout is a good cozy spot, but it has no cell reception to speak of.  

Lots of interesting and tasty beers on tap, as well as a roster of specialty cocktails.  The bourbon drink (derby?) was on the small side and kind of minty/pulpy for my taste, but it didn't bother me enough to take off a star.
author: Andi T.

description: The bartender literally said "we don't know how to make old fashioneds"
author: Brandon W.

description:
I can venture a guess as to why people love this place--they feel cool when they're in the "Hideout." I don't wanna get too Freudian up in here, but I think this claustrophobic cave feeds off our childhood desire to be in an exclusive area doing something really 'secretsy' (i.e. forts, treehouses, clubs, etc.). 

Well now that I'm a grown-up, or something like that, I can feel the difference between being cool and elite and being cold and elitist. Big difference. It seems that Dalva, and their clientele, hasn't quite figured that out yet.

If I may return to the subject of adolescence--Yes, waiting 12 minutes for my Linkin Park song to download on Napster probably made me appreciate my music a little bit more, but waiting 12 minutes for my Manhattan doesn't make me appreciate my drink anymore than if I got it in 2 minutes.

Now that that's out of my system, the drinks were good. Just as good as going to any other place that habitually serves "craft cocktails" (I'm almost certain that's how they would describe their drinks).

I won't pretend to be hipster. I won't even pretend to be hipst. Maybe I caught some attitude because I forgot to wear my flannel out to 16th and Valencia again. Maybe I was just a little too buzzed for their liking. Either way, this is probably the hipstest bar in the Mission, and I'm just not sure how I feel about that. 

I'm not usually one to bash any small business, so 3 stars for them. I would definitely go back (if Delirium, Kilowatt, Monk's Kettle, Elixir, Casanova, and even Double Dutch were all closed).
author: Max S.

description: This review is only for The Hideout because the only thing I know about Dalva is that there is a narrow path to get back to the crafty cocktail bar in the back. The Hideout is so much fun although it seems small and cramped it gets a lot bigger when you get that first drink in you! The cocktails taste amazing and it's almost more fun to watch the master craftsmen engineer your drink. Overall I definitely recommend The Hideout for a couple or small group.
author: William H.

description: I'm a big fan of Dalva!  This slightly-hidden bar on 16th is a great place to grab a drink on weekdays or weekends.  On weekdays, I have found there are always at least a few people so you don't feel weird and on weekend it can be pretty packed.  The front bar is your usual casual Mission bar but there is a back room called "The Hideout" where the bartenders whip up some mean cocktails!  They also play movies on a projector with no sound most of the time which are fun to check out and work well as conversation starters.
author: Liz H.

description:
The hideout in the back is a great place to relax and get away from the 16th street crowd. But don't be in a rush, those fancy drinks come at a price. Everytime I've ordered a round of drinks there it's taken, like forever, to get them made.

Actually, get your order in, go to the front bar and get some beers, sit down. Then go back about 15 mins later to get the cocktails.
author: Geoff H.

description:
Dalva's a good place for good prices on drinks and a glowing orange ambiance.  After an arduous search for parking I arrived and the place was packed with both folks just looking for a drink venue and others pre-gaming for the club.  

It's a small narrow hangout with the bar running along one side and bar tables on the other with larger ones for groups toward the back.  Located even in the further back is an area called "The Hideout" where i met with my group.  The Hideout is a smaller area with elbow to elbow room that gets stuffy and oh so intimate.  The atmosphere was friendly and lively with music playing in the background and some 70's "Shaft"-esque movie playing on a projector screen hanging high on their back wall.  

Aside from hunting for parking Dalva is a great place for drinks and a friendly staff.  Located in the Mission it's easily accessible using public transportation (the preferred mode is you're traveling here during prime happy drink hours).  It's definitely one of the prime spots in the Mission area and worth at least a 2 drink visit if you're hopping around for the night.
author: Brian C.

description:
The music was too damn loud for a casual bar setting. As one of my friends said, music should only be this loud if there is a live band playing. Drinks were poorly made, and people were annoying.

I really find no reason to go here. What are you going to do, sit there and starre at each other? Its too loud to talk, and there is no dance area. What do they expect you to do!??!
author: Caitlin H.

description:
A great spot somewhat hidden to the untrained mission eye. Sandwiched between the Roxie and another spot, its easy to miss this bar when just walking by.

Also located right next to Truly Med... grab a lamb shwarma and go to Dalva for a cold beer or a strong cocktail. There are 3 "places" to sit there. 

One is the main bar area, the other is the "secret" room (not much of a secret really) which has seating downstairs next to a bar in back, and then there is the upstairs.

Its actually a really great spot to book the spot in the back/upstairs when you  have a big party of people coming with you. I believe you need upto 13-ish people to book the upstairs. Grab grub with your big group, bring it upstairs, take over the area and order drinks like you're at a friend's house and chill. (well, except for the fact you're paying for these here drinks).

Its got personality and just the right amount of hipster nocturnal thing going on where its not annoying or obnoxious. Gets pretty crowded on good nights.
author: Anish B.

description: I have not been to Dalva in a few years. It was not as funky as I remembered. The booze selection is better. I came for Karaoke on Sunday with Bartman and had fun!!  I will have to go back.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place earlier.  Met my fiance here over 2 1/2 years ago at a mutual friend's birthday party.  Therefore, gets 5 stars in my book, regardless of drinks, scene, etc.
author: Danielle B.

description:
EDIT: it's been brought to my attention that this isn't the Dalva bathroom, but another classy mission joint. 

Enough people talk about the bar part of this joint. But what about the bathroom? 

Well, good question. Check out that toliet pic... 

Does that count as a LOVE SEAT? 

I've never touched cheek with the dude next to me while I pee; this was almost a first. I'm going back!
author: Kuang C.

description:
Holy crap this place is a classic hole in the wall dive bar. This place does get packed and busy. I met up with a friend of mine here and I had a dark lager that drank deceptively smooth which knocked me on my ass. Of course they have other poisons at your disposal. 

If I lived in the City, I'd be a regular here.
author: Navi T.

description:
Dalva seems like your typical dive bar, dark & dingy. Perfect place to discuss some very shady things over a great beer.  The beer selection is diverse & caused me to have some decision anxiety (I know, rough problem to have right?) The kicker though... there's another bar within the bar... my mind is BLOWN! Hidden in the back is the Hideout. Small, very dark, very intimate.  The red back lit bar gives you just enough light to barely make out the amazing beer & cocktail selection.

In short come here if: you love beer, you & your sig fig love beer, or if you're involved in some shady business and need a place to have your office hours.
author: Danny T.

description:
Do you like to get hot and sweaty with unbathed dudes in fluorescent tights twizzling handlebar mustachios?

No?!

GO TO DALVA.

One of my favorite bars in the city. A good beer selection, awesome prices and some of the friendliest bartenders you'll ever meet. They've even added a posh lounge in the back with swankier cocktails... so you can bring your hot date there to try and impress her, fail miserably, then head back to the front for shots of well whiskey...
author: Keane L.

description: The cozy and low-key Dalva had a pretty simple setup: a long bar counter lined with stools on the left and bar height seating peppered throughout the rest of the joint. Normally a projection screen would show old school B/W Eastern European Kung Fu B-movies, while rock music played in the background, but one night we had a video release party with our friends and bar patrons watching our video on the projection screen. It was a good night! Bartenders Jimmy and Lesley are super friendly.
author: Robin H.

description: very dark in here.  bartenders were nice.... easy to get a drink...drinks were cheap.... crowded but not packed...eclectic, diverse crowd.... chill vibe... music not super loud... all good things.  Nothing super special about it... just a good place to get a drink if you are nearby.  They have taxidermied animals on the wall wearing sunglasses.
author: Easter E.

description:
Last night I decided to drop by this place after the gym... Little did I know it would be the night I had the best drink of my life! 

Cheesy yes, but seriously true. I went to the bar in the back and asked the bartender (didn't catch his name, but I remember he had a shaved head) for a pimm's cup... Which I've had in various bars and even in Europe... I watched as he made my drink with such precision and love haha, it was like a 10 step process, then I drank it and was pretty much immediately in heaven. 

As for the rest of bar, I didn't have the food and the place was kind of dark.. a friend had rented out the upstairs area so that was fun... but be careful on those stairs, too many amazing drinks, could lead to something not so awesome. 

oh and cash only- sucks! it might have only been for the back bar, I'm not sure. They did have a atm machine, but really, transaction fees.. buzz kill!
author: Rona Y.

description:
Dalva is a great place for when your date makes plans with you at 10, but then doesn't show up until nearly 11. Yep that was my experience.

Normally I wouldn't come to such a dive, but I was invited by a potential date. I dragged my friend along so I wouldn't have to wait alone. It was supposed to be poetry night in the back room, but apparently poetry night is a thing of the past.

We arrived and it was elbow to elbow with people. Opted for the Sangria at $5. My friend had a Stella served in a huge pilsner glass also for $5. We thought the bartender said $10 for each, but after her $10 was sitting on the bar counter for much too long we decided to ask the bartender how much our drinks were. No wonder he didn't take the $10 because our drinks were $5. Since I am so inclined to drinking $10 cocktails I gave him the money without hesitation proving my utter confusion.

Bartender was super friendly. DJ sets up in a tiny corner in the front. Music ranged from some barnyard two step..whatever that is..take it as you will. Music got better as the night progressed. 

Whatever happened to my date you ask? Well after 2 glasses of Sangria I invited another friend as my girlfriend had to leave. By the 2nd round he ended up showing up.

This place is great for being stood up as the drinks are fairly cheap! You will be drunk by round 2.
author: Cellina B.

description:
"Ohhhh, Girl, he is Grade-A Prime Rib..."

Where else would you find a homeless transvestite on the street hitting on my date??? Yes, it's just another episode of fun in the Mission District!!! =)

As for the bar, it's got alcohol, a movie playing on the wall and candles -- I've got no complaints. This place is great!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Very laid back place indeed.  I caught a few people smoking in the back, so if that's your thing, you'd probably like it here (They recently put up a no smoking sign).  They played some pretty good music too which is always a draw for a music geek like me.  The Mission has so many great places to hang out and this is one of them.  I've been here on several occasions and it's always been a relatively pleasant one.  There are tables in the back and a few more upstairs if you just want to hang out with your friends with a drink.  The sign says, "We only serve nice people."  So far, it's been that way ever time I've gone here.  Blink and you might miss it behind the Roxie theatre.

Edit: Thumbs down for the nasty bouncer who only let HALF of my party in recently. I dunno if I'm going back cuz once you mess with the bull, you'll get the horns..subtracting a star for that. Every time except this time it's been pleasant.
author: Amy J.

description:
A must stop spot along 16th street, especially on the weekends. 

Awesome beer selection. I probably get a little too excited when I see something on tap that I have yet to try, total excitement overload here. Had the bartender reco Abita Amber and Moose Drool. I felt like the guy knew me. Loved them both. They still have a couple other selections I would like to put back so I'll certainly return. 

The front/main room is where it's at. Nice crowd but not packed. It did get a little congested in the back past the bathroom but not terrible. I was also upstairs in the Hideout. Way too hot up here. I had to make frequent trips downstairs, not just to grab a beer but to cool off. I think the Lasko fan in the window was the same one I had in college. This needs improvement. 

Read some complaints about the bathroom here. It is definitely not aesthetically pleasing but the toilet flushes, the water runs and there were no foul odors. Not bad enough to ruin a night so deal with it and have a good time.
author: Michael C.

description: The bartender in the back is full of himself. "I don't like sweet drinks," I say. He proceeds to tell me "everyone says that". And then recommends a drink from the menu. I trust him. And I drink it but say is a bit sweet. And he tells me it is bc I drank it too slow and "it gets sweeter as it warms up." No...it was just too sweet for me to drink. Second drink...also too sweet. Sorry buddy, you just don't make good cocktails. And there is such a thing as a not sweet cocktail. I've had a few.
author: A F.

description:
Speaking of darkness...our next stop was thoroughly appropriate...Dalva!  Talk about dark...it's always been dark in here for years.  Anyway, great bar although I was surprised that there was only one bartender to service so many customers.  Regardless, I was impressed with his professionalism and how he still took meticulous care in making every single cocktail despite people changing orders midstream (like me) and adding drinks to orders.  He was slammed and yet handled it like a true professional.

Drinks were really good and I loved the kooky (kookie?) fish theme throughout the bar area.  I thought the metal coelocanth above the bar was hilarious.  Not sure if most patrons even know what that is.  Bar stools were kinda cramped, but the people were nice and even moved over one for us.  Fun times!
author: Roy N.

description:
"Huh?! What?! Say that again! Still not getting it... Repeat that!" That's me yelling over the unnecessarily loud music, trying to establish how much my beer cost in this nearly empty bar with terrible acoustics. Toward the back there are a few high tables for 4-5 max with uncomfortable bar stools and, although it was slightly better here, having to yell at the person right next to me and the pounding in my brain so soon after work on a Monday made me anxious to leave the entire time I was here.

Apart from that, Dalva seems to be your typical Mission bar - sparing decor, decent liquor selection, variety of local/indie beers on tap, and choicer imports in bottles. I was happy to see a couple kinds of Chimay and Hitachino, including a large bottle of Hitachino white that was very nice indeed.

So, I guess this is a cool spot with good stuff to drink... but given the quality of the several bars within a block of this place, I doubt I'll return unless invited.
author: Kristina A.

description: First time trying "the hideout", way awesome . I don't think i'd go there on a weekend , but last night it was really cool ...and my "Fruit Cup" was delicious
author: Lauren V.

description: Great place! I suggest you go straight to the back to the second bar (the Hide Out) and grab a drink from that menu. Those bartenders know what they're doing!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Love the front area of Dalva for weeknight chillage, especially for the beer. Happy hour is never so crowded that you can't find a seat, and the variety of beers they have is pretty bomb.

Other yelpers are raving about the Hideout - but it didn't really cut it for me. The ambiance is great - suuuuuper relaxed and loungey without being smarmy. Just the good kind of loungey - like you're in a cute, dimly lit living room. I just wish their cocktails were more delicious (especially for $10-$11 each)... 

The Brooklyn was fine, definitely the best of the three, but plenty of other bars can make this tastier. Their version was fairly sweet, so if you like that, then go for it. 

Whiskey in Church was just...bad. I know they said smokey scotch, but dang this was like drinking a liquid campfire. Where places like the Rickhouse succeed in balancing a crazy ass smokey scotch, the Hideout just failed. None of the amaro or pear flavors came through, and there was just a teeny tiny hint of maple.

Toast and Coffee I guess was alright. But after a couple sips the novelty of drinking it wears off, and I'd much rather be sitting there with actual toast and coffee.
author: Monica C.

description: This place is the best of two worlds. Back bar serving elixirs with the front bar, well just being good at being a regular bar. The dark lighting makes it perfect for a date meet up . After getting saucy saunter over to the Roxie for an art film.
author: Jeff R.

description:
I enjoyed a Moonlight Special here.  I planned on only staying for one drink until my cousin showed up and we would go to dinner down the street.  I stayed for a few more drinks than expected and I wished i could have gone back for more.  If i lived in SF, this would be my drinking spot of choice.  The bartender was friendly and he knows how to mix a damn fine gin and tonic.  
Dalva loses a star because the jukebox wasn't working when I was there.
My cousin showed up and I gave her a big hug.  I downed my beer, sad that I wouldn't be able to return to Dalva before my trip ended.  If I ever go back to SF, I hope to return.
author: Francisco H.

description:
+1 star for the prices

+1 star for the fact that it's a nice low key dive bar in the Mission and not at all grimy.

+1 star for the awesome country and bluegrass on vinyl

minus one star for the shitty house cocktails our frazzled bartender made. The bar wasn't too busy and my Hemingway tasted gross. Unless that's a gross drink to begin with, then I don't know...

+1 more star because I'm nice.
author: Caro M.

description: I stopped here at the end of my night in the mission. I have to say, I liked the music, and the bar was not overheated/overcrowded, which was nice. The cocktails were decent, but nothing incredible. I'd like to come back when I can spend a longer time there.
author: Chris M.

description:
1)  Crowded - not very conducive for a relaxing chill moment with friends
2)  Dingy
3)  Went there for a mixer and didn't meet anyone interesting.  I shouldn't blame the lack of interesting people on the bar but.. I'm projecting nonetheless.
author: Christine B.

description:
I just love Dalva.. It's such a dive but it's always a good time.

I've lived in the hood for over 6 yrs.. come to Dalva all the time.. Had no idea they had that back mixology room with the amazing bartender that makes those amazing concoctions.. AMAZING! Love this place more now..
author: Monica S.

description:
This might be the worst bar I have ever been to in SF.  Actually I know it is the worst bar I have been to in SF.  I can break it down.

I went to Dalva for MK's Madmen event so I was in a suit.  It was also a weekend.  I think that I was pretty much the only guy in a suit, at least a full blown suit.  I am not sure if that had anything to do with my experience or not.

First of all the prior reviews are right on.  The bartenders measure all drinks in measuring cups.  Think about when you were a kid and your mom measured out you medicine by the tablespoon so accurately, that's pretty much how they treat their liquor.  I hate places like that.  There have been numerous studies done that if you pour with a heavy hand you make more money.  Now some will say that that the bloodhound for example does the same thing; not true.  Most of the concoctions that they make that require measurements have more than one alcoholic ingredient.  A manhattan does not, unless you count vermouth and bitters...

So basically what I am saying is that they skimp on the juice i.e. alcohol.  They skimped on the juice all night; yet all night I continued to tip well, throwing 1 or 2 bucks down per drink.  And the drinks are not cheap...

So towards the end of the night I ordered another manhattan and they gave it to me on the rocks.  I asked the bartender if he could serve it "up" and with more alcohol stating that I had been tipping well all night and he yelled at me.  I immediately turned around and walked away.  Didn't bother me at all.  In fact, for me, that was the straw that broke the camel's back.  I left.  Vowed never to return.  Don't think that will have any impact whatsoever on their business but it is my quiet protest.

So if you like hipster bartenders with a bad attitude, that measure your drinks by the tablespoon in the mission then this is definitely the place for you.  If you want a good value for your money I suggest going somewhere else.
author: Anthony Y.

description: Pleasant peeps. Nice little hideout back.
author: Inigo M.

description: Typical bar in the Mission. It was ok considering I was there for the premeire party for Oddities SF.
author: Joe V.

description:
After all my years living here why have I only gone into this place once? 

Dave at the back bar makes it worth while. he makes the best drinks around and plays Motown allllll night. it is like a private little den of loving smooth Sam Cooke and cocktails to die for. 
xoxo 
will be back to dance it up.
author: Mel s.

description:
Sf Weekly highly recommended this place so I thought I give it a go when the time was right and that time was yesterday night when a bunch of us wanted to grab a drink. When I first walked in, nothing stood out to me. Just looked like a regular bar so we waited until "The Hideout" opened which was about 7pm. The Hideout, I would say, was pretty awesome. Cute cozy speak easy feel and the Farrah Faucett poster just made me smile. It was a total contrast from the rabbit with antlers decor they got next to it. 

But it all boils down to drink selection and as a lover of whiskey, the selection blew my mind. It reminded me a bit of bourbon and branch (another bar I love). The posse ordered scotch related drinks and I ordered a whiskey, coffee, orangy taste concoction. One of those got me pretty tipsy.  Top it off, with a 20% industry discount, and I am one jazzed up happy camper. Definitely, would come back to try the rest of the interesting cocktails.

o yeah, the music rocks too!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Weird beer and weird movies on projection. And a dog who wagged his tail furiously with excitement. This place is chilllll (but we were there on a Tuesday).

Moose Drool Brown Ale caught my eye so I had to try it. I was imagining more of a Newcastle Brown Ale taste, but this was much darker and stronger. It was actually closer to a taste of a porter because it was a dark brown ale. Cool vibes I'll be back to taste more beers.
author: Charles L.

description:
Miss Greta G. We DON'T condone Weed Smoking@Dalva! (Everyone check out the Dalva review below) What a way to slam me! you're such a sweetheart. "low-life?" ouch! "Scumbag," that hurts. "Loser," Damn! What gives? By the way, you spelled my name wrong. Its J-A-R-A-D. Next time you come by the bar maybe I need to check your ID a little more closely. We don't let children into the bar, and that is what your recent review of ME, not Dalva, suggests. You're a childish person. Not to mention petty. If you want to discuss it further over a drink, on me of course, let's discuss your absurd "dis." By the way, nice picture of me, you stole it off my personal Myspace page, which suggests you might be a little obsessed? Get a life DORK!
For everyone else, Dalva is the Shit! Come by, have cheap strong drinks, and a hell of a good time! www.myspace.com/dalva_cocktails. CHEERS!
Dalva Management


Say it to my face instead of hiding in computer land!! I don't need to say anything else about it.
author: jarad s.

description:
If anyone actually reads my reviews they will soon realize that I am easily pleased by three things:

1. Mojitos
2. Sangria
3. Burritos

Now Dalvas has an excellent happy hour with 1/2 price Sangria AND I can go over to Pancho Villa and bring my burrito back to the bar and eat and drink in Happy Hour merriment with my ladies. 

2 out of 3 ain't bad folks.
author: Katherine B.

description: Dalva is definitely a great spot to hit up. The beer selection is great, they serve up Russian River's Damnation in a regular ol' pint glass at a pretty good bargain. The bartender was great at helping me sort through the different brews that they have. It's a nice place to chill out and if you happen to sneak into the back there's another bar awaiting you!
author: Stephen S.

description:
As the first bar I went to in San Francisco, Dalva will always hold a special place in my heart. My friend took me here and led me to the back of the bar. At first I wasn't sure what that area was: Cellar? Cave? Lost catacomb of San Francisco? Built over crevasse, a remnant of the 1906 Quake? Whatever that area was, it was dark, quiet and a nice place to have a couple drinks and chat. 

My friend advised me that Dalva has a nice selection of beers, though admittedly I'm the rum and coke type. It's a simple cocktail, but the drink I had was like a hard Roy Rogers: definite cola taste with a splash of sweet grenadine, and a rum kick. It was casual and didn't pass the razzle-dazzle-flair buck onto the customers, which is always nice.
author: Robert L.

description:
Place is dope. Bartenders are super cool. and drinks are cheap and strong. What more can you ask for?..... a clean bathroom!!!!!!

p.s.

please clean it.
author: Aidan V.

description:
While I've never thought Dalva was too special, it was a great place for a crowd of us to celebrate a promotion, a birthday, something while still being close to the action and not being mobbed by large amounts of people. 

First place I've ever had a red bull and vodka. 
I've never been so hyper in my life. If it seems they make the best, I'll add a star.
author: Vee B.

description:
We don't have to take our clothes off to have a good time!

You better not forget this when coming to Dalva.  Sure you're saying, "But Brendon, what else is there to do at Dalva?"  I know it's hard, but sometimes you need to take the advice of Jermaine Stewart:  
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ID_N7rv-iN8

Here's the point, people.  Any place, especially a dark and dank "bar" like this, that plays my boy Jermaine is high on my list of spectacular.  

The bartender was efficient and polite.  What a shock in this area.  

Don't half step.  Don't take your clothes off and watch yourself in this area when the bars close...can be a bit sketchy.
author: Brendon D.

description:
Great drinks in the hideout...the bar within the bar.  

Want to try "Fruit Cup" (Pimm's, gin, lemon, ginger, cucumber, soda, bitters), or "The Stranger" (gin, Cocchi Americano, lemon, honey, herbal liqueur).
author: around town e.

description: I've been on a search for a great hot toddy ever since Ti Couz closed, and I finally found one I like here at Dalva!  I should have gotten the bar tenders name, but he made a delicious one with Lipton tea, brandy and cinnamon.  The bar tender was really nice and they have some very interesting decorations up.. great conversation starters.
author: Laura P.

description: I have always loved this bar! First time i went there is loved the speak easy style bar and the bartender leslie was slinging great cocktails just like they do back home! Fabulous place to meet up with friends and great cocktails!
author: Robert B.

description:
I don't know if Mission district or San Francisco bars in general are best suited for me.  I felt really awkward at all the ones I went to practically, but this was one of the better ones for me.  

The main room was very crowded.  I couldn't even get to the bar.  Good thing we were with big guys that could butt their way in.  But then there was no where to stand so we had to move towards the pool table.  And then we were in their way.  

Also, we had the misfortune of standing next to a group that had dropped their glasses twice and refused to pick it up or tell the bartender about it.  So there was just random glass on the floor.  

I also know that they let underage people in, which isn't a big deal, except that it was really crowded and it just made me crankier.  

We finally made our way into the second room where it turned into a weird prom scene.  People were seated in a huge circle along the wall talking but not dancing.  But that changed after about an hour so it wasn't sooo bad.  

The entertainment was a transgendered woman dancing very brazenly on a small ledge.  I was worried that due to her size she might lose her balance and take out a bunch of people.  But she did it like pro. :)

There was also a tiny arcade room to the side.  And people were smoking inside all the rooms. 

The bathroom was small, but not bad. 

I guess I just don't like crowds too much.  But I did enjoy watching the dancer.
author: Kara S.

description: This place is solidly okay. Decent spot to grab a drink in the Mission. But I don't think there's much special about it. Average drinks, average dark and noisy vibe... Some of the areas in the back are a bit nicer. It's a decent spot but not one I'd go out of my way to visit.
author: Courtney A.

description: Fantastic service and a plethora of terrific drink choices at decent prices.  Proximity to other Mission awesomeness makes this place a stand by.   Me likey, Tommy want wingy.
author: Darin E.

description:
Mojito is strong and fresh. Definitely weak on the cider but pretty sweet. 

Bathroom is horrendous. Had to tiptoe to the toilet to make sure my boots werent touching the pee stained floor. ICK.
author: Silvia K.

description:
Started the night here this Saturday night for a friends Birthday (Happy Birthday Claudia). Its located next to the Roxie Theater so dont blink or else you will miss it. The place is tiny, but guess what, it works. My friends and I hung out at the front room because it was easier for the smokers to have a drag. The bartenders are awesome. I dont think I stood for more than a minute without getting some help or at least a "Be right back". Sometimes just a simple nodding of the head makes me feel like I am not being ignored. The prices are reasonable and they played some pretty good 80's music (I think it was 80's, maybe 90's, whatever). I heard the place to be in is the far room in the back but it was too stuffy for me. 

   If you want a good place to meet some cool people without dipping into your savings account, try Dalva.
author: Edson C.

description: Went here last Sat with my friends for a B-day Party! We had a great time, everyone was nice, drinks were bomb in the back! Good atmosphere. Was a little thrown off by the new age, old west theme, but still loved it! Very hipster which is chill, not my thing but respect to all! :)
author: Natalia H.

description:
Their $7.50 Bulleit Manhattan is reason enough to come to this place, but the old school movies (Caddyshack last night) and the fantastic juke are the icing on the cake.

We spent about an hour and a half here last night, just hangin' out, drinkin' cocktails and shootin' the sh*t. The dark interior with red votives aligning the walls is a nice touch and it wasn't busy at all when we were here. It almost feels like a well kept secret in the Mission.

Definitely coming back for another Manhattan. "On the rocks" here is a good idea if you're going that route. These drinks will put hair on your chest and a swagger in your step!
author: Katie A.

description: Know what you want, but if you're not sure, let the bartender know what type of drink you're looking for, and he'll make a special (tasty) concoction for you.  Fresh mint atop the bar is always a good sign that you're getting a fresh drink versus premixed cocktails.  The Derby is delicious...
author: Natalie G.

description:
One of the best bars in the Mission, hands down.  I appreciate the dim lighting, the quality of the beer and alcohol, and the variety of seating in the main bar and in the Hideout (back area with crafted cocktails and upstairs lounge).  This is a place you can come with your buddies or your date and enjoy some tasty, interesting booze in a low-key setting at your leisure.  

Minus one star for the attitude of the staff.  They are consistently surly.  I know it's the Mission and everything, but really, that's just not necessary. 


For those of you who are gluten-free, they have Ace cider on tap.  Bonus!
author: A. L.

description:
i love the friendly fun vibe here.  the owner is super nice, helped me reserve the upstairs private room without a hitch and was uber responsive.

the only problem with the space is that because the layout of the bar is long and narrow, the hideout backroom gets hot when it's crowded or the weather is on the warmer side.  and the upstairs, well it's pretty much a stifling oven by the time you fill it up with your friends.  they need to get an industrial size fan (or two) up there and that would alleviate the problem.

other than that, drink selection can't be beat and the cocktails are legendary (gimlet is my fave).  the bouncer with the super fro, i think his name is travis is so adorable!
author: Josie M.

description:
I never seem to have anything nice to say about poor Dalva. My friends really like this bar, and some of my more recent retorts to their cries for "Sangria at Dalva!" include...

1. "Ugh. Their jukebox is full of hipster barf."

2. "Their walls are too bare. I feel like I'm in the Tower of London."

3. "IPA tastes BAAAD there."

Are these things true? Well, in my strange little warped world -- yeah. 

BUT... They're also incredibly subjective. And, Dalva may have a few retorts of its own when it sees ME coming...

1. "Oh god. It's the bitch who can't seem to remember that she's ordered the IPA five times before and doesn't like it."

2. "Shit. Are we going to have to listen to ANOTHER drunken rendition of 'Do You Hear the People Sing?'"

I'm sure it has other gripes with me. Because I do go here a lot. I'm apparently the only person I know who has a beef with Dalva.

So I will call it a wash. And 3 stars.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Great job Tom! The meetup happy hour was great success ( Ali G )

Drinks specials, bartenders and company were all loads of fun. I'm surprised I haven't written any review of this place even though I come here once in awhile. 

You certainly can't beat the Pee Wee Herman movie playing at the bar.

You will have your own DYL in no time with or without making out drunk. =P Har Har.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Hidden next to Truly Mediterranean is this small, cheap, lively bar.  Good and plenty beer on tap.  A go-to for surrounding neighbors looking for a bar to call home.  

Sunday night karaoke = highly recommended
author: Gracie L.

description:
I love Dalva. Let me reiterate: I LOVE Dalva. And not only because of the amazing Trumer Pils glasses, one of which I successfully stole last year, but which broke right after I first used it. No, I love Dalva because it's a really relaxed, unpretentious (at least when I'm there), casual bar that offers a great selection of beers and hard liquors, good music, and a good atmosphere. I first went here on a date, and it's a good place for casual drinking with friends, more-than-friends or people you're interested in getting to know a little better. Especially the somewhat scary but overall pretty awesome upstairs room (which is where I plan on going to steal my next glass...). 

Um. I love Dalva. That's pretty much all there is to say. I love Dalva. I love their Trumer glasses. I also love their proximity to Taqueria Pancho Villa (tofu tacooooooos!).

Oh yes. Yes indeed.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Had a post World Series street party date with a mixologist obsessed crew. Bypassed the front bar, DJ painter Kevin and headed straight back to the Hideout. Want: custom cocktails with a crooked smile. 

Try to resist the urge to order off the menu and have Josh mix up whatever comes to mind. Bourbon, tequila, sweet, savory, even spicy - the man has a gift. I can't imagine a better place to be locked-in from the riotous streets of San Francisco after a World Series killing.
author: Manuela Z.

description:
16th Street is a drunken mess of a street. This is an easy street if you're looking for bars, clubs, and food. I'm not a big fan of this street but Dalva is ok. It's mellow. It's never overcrowded and stuffy. However if by chance it is a bit crowded and it's tough to get a drink at the bar don't fret. There's an entire cozy backroom area (Hideout) with another bar and more seating. 

A Bulleit rocks cost me $7. A little higher than I'm used to but then again I'm used to dirty divey bars where drinks are cheap.
author: David C.

description:
we came here on a wednesday night for a friends going away. he told us that he yelped 'dive bar' and dalva is the best that came up and this place is pretty cool.

we came in before 7 so they had some drinks on special for $3.75.  i originally was just going to get a mojito to sip on but asked the bartender what he made that was good.  he said he had some fresh tangelos.  he made me a tangelo daiquiri.  it was so good.  i had 2!

they have a little back room, a juke box with about 2 songs that i know, and stairs that lead to i dont know where.  the walls have grates on them.  weird.  but ok

the drink was good!
author: claudia y.

description:
There's no shortage of bars on 16th street in the Mission, but there is a shortage of bars where you can get a good cocktail and friendly service.

Dalva is one of my favorite bars in the city. They make awesome martinis at reasonable prices. The back room (Hideout) is perfect for a small group.

The owner and bartenders are super friendly.

I don't usually expect quality in the Mission, but they take their drinks and their service very seriously at Dalva. I love it.
author: Sachin A.

description: I have been going to Dalva for eons and eons and I always have a good time here-especially in the back where we used to smoke ( I said eons).  Good drinks, the bar staff is on top of it and no nonsense and the space is set up pretty well. The Hideout is now my one of my favorite watering holes. Oddly enough, I like it when it's crowded and when it slow. It is NOT however, a good place for a second date as I recently found out--too dark, if you can believe it!
author: Uda W.

description:
quite possibly one of the worst bars i've ever been to in my entire life.  the people giving this place 5 stars must have some mild form of retardation.  even for a dive bar it sucks.  

we got there and it was dead, yet it still took the girl behind the bar 10 full minutes to acknowledge me, and that was after she poured herself a shot.  she saw me standing there with my credit card yet failed to tell me "cash only" until AFTER she poured our drinks.  at that point her attitude had been so sour that i simply told her "keep 'em" and walked to the back where our friends were sitting.

sitting in the back in "the hideout" was actually pretty decent, and the only reason this review gets 2 stars vs just 1.  the bartender in the back was really nice and as i had run out to get some cash after the debacle with the girl up front i gladly bought a round.  the Gin and Celery's are fantastic, i highly recommend.

would i go back?  not a chance, not even if i was dying and the only way to get the cure was to deal with that horrible blonde up front.  

avoid at all costs...
author: Robert M.

description:
At the seventh bar of Christmas I bought myself for me:
One Fernet
One PBR
One PBR
One Jack and Coke
One PBR
One vodka Red Bull
One pint of PBR
You can't smoke cigarettes nor weed all day upstairs anymore: 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B91wki_jQf0
It's what you were, Dalva that makes it impossible to grant you five stars for what you are.
Aside for that, for a small bar on 16th and Valencia, Dalva is quaint and romantic.
Great music, quality conversation if you want it - though people will leave you alone here.
DEFINITELY the easiest bar on the Valencia strip, when I'm around here I'm always sure to check in for a drink.
author: Theo R.

description:
I almost got in a fight here. And I know what you're thinking, "Stephy?! Sweet, innocent, demure, waif-like (yeah right) little Stephy?" *Gasp!* "Never!"

Well, it's true. I have been in a scrap or three in my years and the night it almost happened here, would have been justifiable because a girl violated....

The Bathroom Door Rule.

Allow me to explain. It's a bar. There are chicks. This means that the drink to bladder ratio gets challenging. There is the magical thing called the "seal" but once that is broken, well, you are as they say in some countries, "screwed." Well, on my first weekend as a SF resident, we came here for drinks and my seal was definitely annihilated. And so, I did what any lady would do and excused myself and went to the ladies room. It was towards the end of the night and as seals go, many were in similar states as mine, but here's where the line was crossed.

As I walked over to the door, I reached for the handle and saw that it was locked. Cool, no worries, I will wait for the young lady to finish. I did, she came out and then I walked in and closed the door behind me. Then not 3 seconds. Count them. 1,2,3 seconds later, someone starts pounding on the door. I'm not talking, "Helloooo, is anyone in there, may I borrow some sugar" knocking, but more like a "Bitch Betta Have My Monaaaay. )(@#&#%)(&!!!" pound. That, my dear friends, is totally un#@&!ingacceptable.

And so I did my business for all of 45 seconds. Did the pounding end? Newp. Did it dull in its rudeness and volume? Newp. Did it piss me the hell off. Oh you bet, and so when I opened the door, I practically hit the broad with the door (intentionally of course) and got right up in her face and said, "45 seconds! Really. You can't wait 45 fucking seconds!" To which she responded some gibberish about kicking my keester. Yeah, yeah, yeah, suck it. I was new to town and wasn't all that interested in destroying the girl on a Saturday night and an arrest may have affected my first day at work, so I opted out. But believe me, the temptation was there to knock Impatient Patty the fuck out!

Anyhoo, I came here again last night and definitely had a much nicer experience. There weren't any drunk and unruly broads, just nice, friendly faces and some great nipple art on the wall. I know that sounds weird, but go in and look, this artist is awesome. I had the wine and I will say, it's not the best, but who orders wine at a bar anyway? No biggie and I will definitely be back again :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
I didn't intend to come here, but am kinda glad that I did. We were just wandering down Mission, not sure where we were going to end up. It occured to me at one point that maybe we should just call it a night. Bars on a Friday in the Mission are not only crowded, but generally crowded with really annoying people that I want to stab. 

We walked by this place and I just happened to glance in. The only thing I noticed was that it wasn't packed with people, so we went inside and immediately found a table against the wall. 

It was suitably dark, which always works to my advantage because I like to do sneaky things to my dates under the cover of darkness. There was a DJ spinning cool hip-hop, and a projection screen in the back was playing a retro 70s movie. 

They have a really extensive selection of beers I'm not familiar with. I ordered the one that looked like it had a dead body in a coffin on the handle. It tasted delicious and I'll have to go back to get the name of it. Some beers are served in these really weird beaker-like glasses that make people look as if they're guzzling their 10th grade chemistry class assignment. 

People here were....normal....I don't know what it is about Dalva that repels all the people I want to stab, but none of them found there way here. Maybe it was just dumb luck, but I don't care.
author: Pamela D.

description: I've ended up here on many a Mission Pub Crawl and hands down my favorite part of the bar is the back area "Hideout".  I've never been let down and the drinks are both cheap and delicious (although in full disclosure, this has never been the 1st stop of our tour de Mission).  Also good to note, the Hideout is bookable for groups (e.g. birthdays).
author: Sean H.

description: This is for the back part the Hideout room.  If you appreciate a good cocktail is is one of the best places to be in SF.   I had a Moscow Mule and my friend had a French Seventy-Five.  The drinks were made with the extreme skill and the bar tender and fellow drinkers were all super cool.  Love this place!
author: Rebecca F.

description:
Why is it that I've never written a review of this all-time favorite bar? Dalva feels like my living room should I actually have one with a full bar and jukebox. They project campy old horror movies like "Blacula" and "The Dagger Killers." 

Dalva was my favorite bar when I first moved to the city in the mid-90s and has retained its distinct identity. It's cool without trying to be, which is more than I can say for 90% of the chodesters (hipster chodes) that troll its surrounding streets.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
Darkness, sangria, and good looking male bartenders. Why don't more women hang out here?

I always meet the most interesting people in the back room. And the chats are completely random but always memorable. A few years ago some guy back there told me to check out Koh Tao when I was traveling around Asia. I ended up living there for a year.

Good blind date meeting place because it's easy to get to (one block from 16th and Mission BART), the drinks are delicious and varied, and the lighting, or lack thereof, makes everyone look pretty.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Dalva has a lot going for it when it's not too crowded. Nicely decorated but comfortable, and a respectable beer selection. A few things to keep in mind while there:

DO NOT GO IN THE DARK ROOM IN BACK where the kegs are; I just looked in there and I got a bad bad feeling about it. It's probably safe if you're a barback and you have business in there, but everyone else should stay out.

In fact, the whole back room seems like it would be used to store canned fruits and gardening tools if it wasn't full of people drinking.

There's a hole in the ceiling in the mens bathroom right above the toilet. It's best not to think about where it leads. If you get kicked out of heaven for asking too many questions I bet you'd fall through that hole.

Be patient. The bartender is a busy man and he marches to his own drummer.

A lot of the drink prices end in .25, so you'll get quarters back. Dalva is a great place to come if you like playing pinball or reading the newspaper.

That is all.
author: matthew r.

description: God, I love Dalva on Thursday night.  Great whiskey selection, tasty chicharrones, homemade tinctures, and a cozy back bar.  Other notables: they have a rotating bourbon/rye flight and Willett evidently stops by occasionally.  If you want a chill place to sit and sip on something delicious, then you can't go wrong here.
author: Matt G.

description: This is a nice bar that's not too divey and not too fancy, has cheap good booze, good bartenders, and projected weird movies. And a whole other bar in back!
author: Klevin D.

description:
So you've probably noticed if you take the time to read any of the stuff I bother to write with the narcissistic delusion that strangers in the world give a shit about what I think about anything, or everything, as the case may be . . . that I give a lot of 5-star reviews. Here's the thing - there are places I hate, but why pollute the internets with vitriol unless someone really does me wrong, or someplace is so horrible that I feel the need to warn others off?  So I don't write a lot of 1 and 2 star reviews - a few, but not many. 

Likewise, I am disinclined to write a review of a mediocre place at all - mediocrity does not warrant my commentary.

That leaves lots of 5-star enthusiasm for the places I really like.

I really like Dalva.  I like the beers on tap.  I like the DJ spinning stuff I've never heard.  I like the lighting.  I like the old wooden bar.  I like the room in the back.  I like that they'll accommodate a big party.  I like that it's just a little grungy, but mostly kinda nice in there.

I like Dalva - get it?  Any questions?
author: Joe C.

description:
This is Lazlo*'s dimly lit sexpot older sister.  Or maybe it's the younger sister.  Or maybe they're not related, but, like, dating**.  Anyway, from the music to the movie projector to the awesome drink selection (especially for microbrews), the sibling bars bear striking resemblence.  I prefer the location and the space of Dalva - there's something like a pulsating candle, something cavernlike about it***.  This is definitely a place to keep it classy in the Mission - conspicuous absence of the more obnoxious varietal of hipster, as well as those desperate college seniors that hang out at Cassanova.  It's not too noisy or too crowded, especially compared to its neighbors.  A nice spot to start or end the night, and definitely date-worthy.  

*http://www.yelp.com/biz/laszlo-san-francisco 
**I went here with my brother.  No one ever mistakes us for dating, thank gawd.  
***though this may be partially due to its unfortunate narrowness.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This is pretty much the sexiest bar in town.

Any place that offers sangria without having to buy accompanying patatas bravas is the kind of place I like to patronize. Even better, it's only $2.75 at happy hour. Which happens on Sundays for some ridiculously long time in the evening. Rad.

There are many neat things about Dalva: the hideout (where you may or may not be able to spark up a cancer stick), the gorgeous art deco bar, and the ladies room. Yes, the ladies room. It's good for two reasons: it's got excellent water pressure for handwashing, and when you're in there with the door closed, you can hear everything your friends are saying about you clear as day.

Dalva. It's like a cool ass secret fort.
author: Megan W.

description: Probably my favorite spot in this immediate area.  It appears rather small from the street, but there is a lot of space - particularly when the upstairs room is also open.  Good beer selection, strong drinks, inventive cocktails at the back bar, fair prices.  It can be pretty noisy on a busy night, but which Mission bar isn't?   Awesome bartenders and bar backs as well - good attitudes, funny, friendly - that can't be easy with the clientele they deal with on the typical Saturday night.
author: Heidi M.

description: If you want to order a beer, go here or anywhere.  If you want to order a $10 martini where the bartender doesn't even have the decency to fill a small glass with alcohol, and explains that the shots are measured, go here too.  Or just go to the Marriott.  They also measure their shots there and overcharge.
author: Ben R.

description:
Pros - Good cocktails. Typical mission dive. Interesting art on display. 

Cons - Bartenders have a slight attitude.  Music so-so.
author: Shruti Y.

description:
Very chillllll... lots of distractions if that's what you're looking for.

Worth stopping in and having a few happy hour drinks if you're on 16th St.


Added bonus: mentioned in the 3eb song "Wounded," so if you're a 3eb fan, you have to go there for the effect.
author: Paul B.

description: I didn't know this place was also a club, but when it is NOT a club and only a bar, I think it's a pretty ideal location to bring a casual date, meet a couple friends for drinks, or kill time over cocktails and goldfish crackers (!!!!) while waiting for a table to open up at Monk's Kettle.  The decor is pretty classy and the volume perfect for indoor voices.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Another Happy Hour, another hangover...as the location of this weeks Happy Hour Dalva served admirably - the specials were great and the crowd was chill...I partook of one (or two) too many double Sangria's and have been paying for it all day but no regrets.

Added bonus - the super secret smoking area in the back is great for those inclined to be social and want to catch a smoke.

I definitely would recommend Dalva as a great place to kick back enjoy Happy Hour at...I will definitely be going back to partake again but next time I will moderate my Sangria intake as a red wine hangover is just one of those things that makes you wish for death or unconsciousness.
author: Todd E.

description:
I first went to Dalva many years ago on a date, and enjoyed my first mojito that night (no, that's not a euphemism)...while the woman came and went (no, that's not an innuendo), the mojitos have hung around, occasionally rearing their minty heads to say 'Hey stranger, wanna party?'.

Oh wait, this is a review about Dalva, and not a showcase for my pathetic attempts at humor? Oops...

So, I just went to Dalva for the second time on Todd E's latest installment of the 'Destroy Your Liver 2006' tour, and this place was just as sweet as I remembered it! The drinks are strong and fairly priced, the staff is cool, and the layout guarantees that you'll definitely find a place to hang...the 'secret' back room even ensures that smokers are not banished into the outside world...

The location is also perfect, because it allows you to easily stumble somewhere to grab some grub before coming back to re-initiate the assault on your liver...

It had been too long between visits to Dalva...but it's nice to know that it forgave me and welcomed me back with open arms...open arms holding a bottle of booze in each hand.
author: Art D.

description:
Dalva is a good bar.  I am writing this after leaving there at 1:30am on a Saturday night.  That's right, a Saturday night in the Mission, out with all of the drunks (present company NOT excluded) and I'm not saying anything bad or judgmental.  Now that's something!

I will say that we tried to go to Double Dutch first and it was sardine-can full of people listening to MC Hammer, and that made us run in the direction of Dalva as quick as bunnies.

Dalva has always been a good staple - kind of a non-descript , low key place to hang with your friends.  They play decent grooves and the crowd is mixed in a good way.  Bartenders are nice and make a good, strong cocktail.  On the big screen TV tonight, they were playing some movie about Evil Knievel and that made many people in my party smile.  60's music, 70's icon - what's not to like?

I usually reach that "hit the wall" moment at Dalva.  If you're going to end your night on the town somewhere, Dalva is a better-than-average place to do it.

Oh, and this night will forever go down in history as the night one of our friends coined the term "re-drunk".  That's when you have been drinking for such a long time that you've been drunk, sober, and then drunk again, all in the same day/night.  Good times.
author: Liz S.

description:
I love sake...I love unfiltered sake even more...I love free unfiltered sake the best.

So, I am there with a few folks, sitting at the bar and had requested only some ice water as I had already had some Wyder Pear Cider at Little Star and was worried that this could be another fainting evening.  The bartender gives me a glass of water with ice and two green straw stirrers.

I am sitting there toying with my stirrers and say to my friend: they are sorta like chopsticks.

She says: I will give you $5 if you can pick up an ice cube with the stirrers and bring it to your mouth.

I love a challenge.  What can I say about my attempts...it's like picking up ice.  With two bendy flexible thin straws.

She's laughing: Actually, I will give you $10.

Me: Can I use both hands?

She: Only if both hands are on the straws.

But I am determined to do this the right way.  I am determined to prove my Korean steel-chopstick using skills.  Yeah, you know we Koreans are the baddest of all chopstick users.

Determination pays off.  And good luck.  Thank god the bar has a lip on the counter that I grabbed while laughing my ass off so I wouldn't fall off the stool.

She didn't have a $10, but she did get me the unfiltered sake.
author: Sooj O.

description:
This is a fun little bar with decently priced booze and KJ Paul laying down some karaoke stylings on Sundays from 9:30 to 2am.  Dalva is stop two on my Sunday karaoke benders.  

They have a back room that hosts an open mic as well.
author: Suzanne C.

description: The Mission's got a whole lotta these types of bars: dark, sticky, stale beer stinky, used to be a *real* dive now trendy, old (usually neon) sign havin', cash only, wall art havin' holes-in-the-wall.  (Oh, and this one has 2 dollar Sierra Nevada pints on Wednesdays after 9.)
author: Rick H.

description:
Here's what just drives me nuts. Abuse of the common sense law. If I'm at a bar that's not crowded and the bartender is hassling me to hurry up and order my drink so he can tend to the waiting customers he doesn't have... fuck that. If it were crowded, that's one thing. If it's not crowded, get over yourself bartender. I just hate it when they're dicks.

Anyway, what I like about Dalva is their top secret back room where they sometimes host poetry slams. During said poetry slam sesh people are bound to be smoking hellza weed so be prepared to get face slammed by a fat cloud of smoke when you walk in. As soon as the smoke settles though, and as long as you can cope with how hot it gets in that little place, the top secret room can be way cool.
author: C P.

description:
I really don't understand while Dalva gets a bad rap.  On a street full of scensterific dive bars, it somehow gets ignored.

Well, the hipsters' loss is my gain, cause when I need lowkey, Dalva is where I go.  They show movies there at night, and the atmosphere is always mellow.  Where as at Dasanova or Delirium you'll be fighting your way to the bar, Dalva has a leisurely stroll.

And their drinks?  Strong & cheap.  And even better at happy hour, when they have $2.75 drafts & sangria.

Need an oasis of calm in the mission?  Stop by Dalva for a pint.
author: Steve S.

description:
Intended to hang in the garden at Zeitgeist today with my brother, a guy, and a girl.  We all met at the Zeit but the bar was packed 5 people back.  Not good.  I've been dry all weekend...I want a Guinness in the sun!  Go out back...forgetaboutit...thought I was big in SF but obviously not THAT big because I don't see one face I know...

Switch gears.

All six eye's look at me concerned...we're outta here.  On to Dalva!   

I love Dalva.  Been going to Dalva for over ten years. We walk into Dalva and the bar is empty and, the friendly bartender (note friendly bartender here!) says he's got crazy specials right at this moment.  God Bless that bartender with the Sebastian Bach hair and the friendly smile.  All domestic tap beers are $2.75.  We'll take two Anchor Summerfests, one Prohibition, and a Ketel One Martini (DK loves her martini's and, you're not much if you're not Dutch!).  

Never once did we wait for our drinks plus, great music, friendly bartenders, no wait for the WC.  If you're sweet on someone and want a cozy nook to kiss on a Sunday afternoon, this is your place.  The back room was empty the whole time.

I know Dalva can be crowded on weekends and this review is being written after a Sunday afternoon but, in the over ten years I've been going to Dalva, I always have a positive experience.  They used to be known for the best jukebox in SF.  Other bars have copied the whole cool jukebox thing...that's okay.  I know Dalva is one of the first cool dive, "hip" neighborhood bars and people might not think it's so hip anymore but, that's what makes it still one of the great bars.   

Yeah Dalva!
author: James M.

description:
I have come to Dalva for 5+ years for two main purposes: to meet up for an HH drink or two before going to an event elsewhere in the Mish, and to attend big group parties in the back room, which you can reserve in advance. 

I guess I've been at the main bar more recently than the back room, because on Saturday I was pleasantly surprised by the addition of 1) a 2nd bar in the back and 2) additional room for tables upstairs. 

The bartenders have also adopted the artisan cocktail trend--no more generic garnies or mixes!  Drinks are made thoughtfully and painstakingly. The prices have gone up accordingly, but since I generally prefer quality over quantity when imbibing, I am on board. 

My BFF's birthday bash upstairs was great!  There was room for 20 people to sit and we only had to gently rebuff non-guests a few times--upstairs is still kind of hidden!  And the 2nd bar made it waaaaay easier to refresh our drinks.  Yes, you'll still have to wait, but it's much easier than trying to claw your way to the main bar on a Saturday night. Well done, Dalva. Carry on.
author: Micah P.

description:
This place gets three stars only for the awesome B movie that was showing on Saturday night (which I found out later was Airport '77...aptly named after my birth year).

Dalva is convenient if you're in the area...but to be honest, it seems more of a happy hour place to me.  It's quite small and doesn't have much atmosphere other than the cliched moody darkness.

Drinks were alright and from what I could see of the crowd, they seemed 20's/30's...but it wouldn't be my first choice of bars to frequent in the Mission.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Last night was a Nat Sherman kind of night, so of course we went to Dalva.  Where else can you go to laugh and cry over bullet manhattans and chain smoke?  

While the bar itself is nothing special, it has a warm, low lit back room worthy of conspiratorial conversation, make-out sessions and joint rolling shenanigans.

I recommend going on a weeknight when the flow is slow and steady.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Dalva is a dark, loud little joint situated close to BART and lots of little cheap late night eats. My friend and I were amused by the menu, seeing as it is pieces of paper cut out and pasted on a wall behind the bar. Luckily for us they has Sierra Nevada on tap and we had a throw-back to our college days. 

The dj was providing some enjoyable music and we lucked out on some seats along the wall. Perfect for people watching and seeing the drinkers wander in off the streets. I also loved the screen on the back wall with black and white pictures showing and the wild coasters with the barmaid on them.
author: Natalie N.

description: Favorite cocktail bar. Head to the back room because they have a different menu and prepare to be rocked. The price is 10-12 so pretty standard and there somehow was not much of a crowd, even past midnight on a Friday night. If you want to enjoy some awesome cocktails and hang out with friends, this is perfect.
author: Ojus P.

description:
Dalva is a nice little mellow respite from the other 16th and Mission bars.  Yeah it's a bit divey, but not in a "hey look how divey we are!" kind of way.  

It's just a small little place, really low-lit with loud music and random movies projected on the back wall.  I've only been here on weeknights so it's always SUPER mellow, so I can't really say how it gets on weekends.  But from my experience the bartenders are cool and the drinks are just fine.

Apparently there is also a back room for smoking, which I've never been into.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Danke, Dalva, for being one of those places where you can meet a date, regardless of where your final destination may be (though, yes, every date I've met here has turned out to be one of those "no sparks" kind of things.  C'est dommage, n'est-ce pas?).  It's easy to get to, it's non-threatening, the little tables next to the wall are strangely intimate, and the back room simply rocks!

Merci, Dalva, for having a wonderfully laid-back set-up.  It's pretty damn easy to get to the bar, and - thanks to the attentive barkeeps - it's also pretty damn easy to get your drink(s) quick.  I don't think I've ever had a bad experience here, if only you will quietly discount the failed dates that have originated here.

Gracias, Dalva, for the music.  Yeah, your jukebox reigns supreme, but the last couple of times I've poked my face into your front door, you've had a pretty decent DJ, haven't you?  Siouxsie, Depeche, Cure, Joy Division, Bjork, Sex Pistols, Birthday Party, Bauhaus, Peaches?  Check, check, check, check, check, check, check, check and CHECK.  Bad-ass fucking music goes long in my memory, mate.

Although I can't really speak out for the failed or no-spark dates that have originated here, I'm not gonna hold you accountable.  Dalva's a bit like an aged velvet glove that's past it's glory days, but still fits like ... uh, a glove ... and is comfortable at that.  Great fucking joint.  

Though next time I go, I'm going by myself.  Fuck dates.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Drinks are cheap! Two cocktails plus a $3-tip for only $16!

We came here on a Friday night at about 10:30ish. It wasn't packed, but was bustling. Very very loud place with a nice projector screen. I felt like I was yelling for hours, but we were only in there for about 30 minutes.

I'd come here again because the drinks are pretty good and it's cheap. And it's right across the street from my boyfriend's...so no need to walk far. =)
author: Angela H.

description:
Like a lot of things, Dalva is probably a bit over my head.  Maybe it's the omissions  that people like? I like old movies too but I like to hear the sound.  I like a good DJ too but the acoustics in here were pretty bad.  I like beer too but I can't really order good ones if I can't see the taps.  Not a bad joint but I don't quite get it.

I did get a free pack of stolen Sherman's out of the stop.  If those were yours you can have 'em back, they're making me cough.
author: Jared L.

description: Excellent beer selection at pretty affordable prices. Good emphasis on local breweries from around the bay area (particularly Moonlight Brewing Co.).
author: Steve K.

description:
Hell's yeah...this is long running fav bar in the city.

-First time I had a Mojito
-Small room in the back. If your cool about it you might be able to have a smoke back there.
-They play Apocalypse Now, and Steve McQueen movies on a regular basis..or at least when I'm there.
-DJ Toph One and the Red Wine Wednesday nights 
-Ticky Ricky is the best bartender
Good Juke
author: Bill M.

description: I'll keep it plain and simple, it's like a party in a closet.  But a fun party none-the-less.  There's a hidden treasure in the back.  Me likey the Dalva
author: Edrian D.

description:
Taking into consideration its 16th St location, I never thought that a bar this accessible would be this decent.  Also, with Dalva being a few doors down from the scene-y meat market Delerium (where it seems that former Arrow Bar clientele have taken up residence), I never thought that it would be this unpretentious.

Along with Mission Bar, this is one of my favorite Mission dives because of the mixed crowd, cool tunes playing on the jukebox, cheap drinks, and laid back vibe.
author: Momo R.

description:
I don't think I've ever actually had a drink in the bar area.  I usually arrive already drunk and I make a beeline straight for the back room.  From there, I start to chain smoke and jive talk.  I don't know how I end up with drinks in my hand, but it happens.  I'm pretty sure the drinks are pricier than other bars in the area, because I always end up a few bills lighter.

I'm reading this review and it totally sounds like I get roofied/robbed at Dalvas.  But it's not true!  This is a cool spot if you're a smoker and don't want to deal with the cold Zeitgeist yard.
author: Meh M.

description:
